House; Berg writes that, "in access and influence, [House] outranked everybody in secondnameplaceholder's Cabinet."[107]secondnameplaceholder introduced a comprehensive program of domestic legislation at the outset of his administration, something no president had ever done before.[109] He had four major domestic priorities: the conservation of natural resources, banking reform, tariff reduction, and equal access to raw materials, which would be accomplished in part through the regulation of trusts.[110] secondnameplaceholder introduced these proposals in April 1913 in a speech delivered to a joint session of Congress, becoming the first president since John Adams to address Congress in person.[111] secondnameplaceholder's first two years in office largely focused on the implementation of his New Freedom domestic agenda.   With the outbreak of World War I in 1914, foreign affairs would increasingly dominate his presidency.[112]Democrats had long seen high tariff rates as equivalent to unfair taxes on consumers, and tariff reduction was their first priority.[113] He argued that the system of high tariffs "cuts us off from our proper part in the commerce of the world, violates the just principles of taxation, and makes the government a facile instrument in the hands of private interests."[114] By late May 1913, House Majority Leader Oscar Underwood had passed a bill in the House that cut the average tariff rate by 10 percent and imposed a tax on personal income above $4,000.[115] Underwood's bill represented the largest downward revision of the tariff since the Civil War. It aggressively cut rates for raw materials, goods deemed to be "necessities," and products produced domestically by trusts, but it retained higher tariff rates for luxury goods.[116] Passage of tariff bill in the Senate was a challenge. Some Southern and Western Democrats wanted the continued protection of their wool and sugar industries, and Democrats had a narrower majority in the upper house.[113] secondnameplaceholder met extensively with Democratic senators and appealed directly to the people through the press. After weeks of hearings and debate, secondnameplaceholder and Secretary of State Bryan managed to unite Senate Democrats behind the bill.[115] The Senate voted 44 to 37 in favor of the bill, with only one Democrat voting against it and only one Republican voting for it. secondnameplaceholder signed the Revenue Act of 1913 (called the Underwood Tariff) into law on October 3, 1913.[115] The Revenue Act of 1913 reduced tariffs and replaced the lost revenue with a federal income tax of one percent on incomes above $3,000, affecting the richest three percent of the population.[117] The policies of the secondnameplaceholder administration had a durable impact on the composition of government revenue, which would now primarily come from taxation rather than tariffs.[118]secondnameplaceholder did not wait to complete the Revenue Act of 1913 before proceeding to the next item on his agenda—banking. By the time secondnameplaceholder took office, countries like Britain and Germany had established government-run central banks, but the United States had not had a central bank since the Bank War of the 1830s.[119] In the aftermath of the nationwide financial crisis in 1907, there was general agreement to create some sort of central banking system to provide a more elastic currency and to coordinate responses to financial panics. secondnameplaceholder sought a middle ground between progressives such as Bryan and conservative Republicans like Nelson Aldrich, who, as chairman of the National Monetary Commission, had put forward a plan for a central bank that would give private financial interests a large degree of control over the monetary system.[120] secondnameplaceholder declared that the banking system must be "public not private, [and] must be vested in the government itself so that the banks must be the instruments, not the masters, of business."[121]Democrats crafted a compromise plan in which private banks would control twelve regional Federal Reserve Banks, but a controlling interest in the system was placed in a central board filled with presidential appointees. secondnameplaceholder convinced Democrats on the left that the new plan met their demands.[122] Finally the Senate voted 54–34 to approve the Federal Reserve Act.[123] The new system began operations in 1915, and it played a key role in financing the Allied and American war efforts in World War I.[124]Having passed major legislation lowering the tariff and reforming the banking structure, secondnameplaceholder next sought antitrust legislation to enhance the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890.[125] The Sherman Antitrust Act barred any "contract, combination...or conspiracy, in restraint of trade," but had proved ineffective in preventing the rise of large business combinations known as trusts.[126] An elite group of businessmen dominated the boards of major banks and railroads, and they used their power to prevent competition by new companies.[127] With secondnameplaceholder's support, Congressman Henry Clayton, Jr. introduced a bill that would ban several anti-competitive practices such discriminatory pricing, tying, exclusive dealing, and interlocking directorates.[128] As the difficulty of banning all anti-competitive practices via legislation became clear, secondnameplaceholder came to back legislation that would create a new agency, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), to investigate antitrust violations and enforce antitrust laws independently of the Justice Department. With bipartisan support, Congress passed the Federal Trade Commission Act of 1914, which incorporated secondnameplaceholder's ideas regarding the FTC.[129] One month after signing the Federal Trade Commission Act of 1914, secondnameplaceholder signed the Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914, which built on the Sherman Act by defining and banning several anti-competitive practices.[130]secondnameplaceholder thought a child labor law would probably be unconstitutional but reversed himself in 1916 with a close election approaching. In 1916, after intense campaigns by the National Child Labor Committee (NCLC) and the National Consumers League, the Congress passed the Keating–Owen Act, making it illegal to ship goods in interstate commerce if they were made in factories employing children under specified ages. Southern Democrats were opposed but did not filibuster. secondnameplaceholder endorsed the bill at the last minute under pressure from party leaders who stressed how popular the idea was, especially among the emerging class of women voters.  He told Democratic Congressmen they needed to pass this law and also a workman's compensation law to satisfy the national progressive movement and to win the 1916 election against a reunited GOP. It was the first federal child labor law. However, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down the law in Hammer v. Dagenhart (1918). Congress then passed a law taxing businesses that used child labor, but that was struck down by the Supreme Court in Bailey v. Drexel Furniture (1923). Child labor was finally ended in the 1930s.[131]  He approved the goal of upgrading the harsh working conditions for merchant sailors and signed LaFollette's Seamen's Act of 1915.[132]secondnameplaceholder called on the Labor Department to mediate conflicts between labor and management. In 1914, secondnameplaceholder dispatched soldiers to help bring an end to the Colorado Coalfield War, one of the deadliest labor disputes in American history.[133] In 1916 he pushed Congress to enact the eight-hour work day for railroad workers, which ended a major strike. It was "the boldest intervention in labor relations that any president had yet attempted."[134]secondnameplaceholder disliked the excessive government involvement in the Federal Farm Loan Act, which created twelve regional banks empowered to provide low-interest loans to farmers. Nevertheless, he needed the farm vote to survive the upcoming 1916 election, so he signed it.[135]secondnameplaceholder embraced the long-standing Democratic policy against owning colonies, and he worked for the gradual autonomy and ultimate independence of the Philippines, which had been acquired in 1898. secondnameplaceholder increased self-governance on the islands by granting Filipinos greater control over the Philippine Legislature. The Jones Act of 1916 committed the United States to the eventual independence of the Philippines; independence would take place in 1946.[136] In 1916, secondnameplaceholder purchased by treaty the Danish West Indies, renamed as the United States Virgin Islands.[137]Immigration from Europe practically ended when the World War began and he paid little attention to the issue. However, unlike the Republicans, secondnameplaceholder looked favorably on the new immigrants from southern and eastern Europe and twice vetoed laws to restrict their entry, but Congress overrode the second veto.[138]secondnameplaceholder nominated three men to the United States Supreme Court, all of whom were confirmed by the U.S. Senate. He nominated James Clark McReynolds in 1914; he was an arch-conservative who served until 1941. In 1916, secondnameplaceholder nominated Louis Brandeis to the Court, setting off a major debate in the Senate over Brandeis's progressive ideology and his religion; Brandeis was the first Jewsish nominee to the court. Ultimately, secondnameplaceholder was able to convince Senate Democrats to vote for Brandeis, who served as an arch-liberal until 1939. Also in 1916, secondnameplaceholder appointed John Hessin Clarke, a progressive lawyer who served until his resignation in 1922.[139]secondnameplaceholder sought to move away from the foreign policy of his predecessors, which he viewed as imperialistic, and he rejected Taft's Dollar Diplomacy.[140] Nonetheless, he frequently intervened in Latin American affairs, saying in 1913: "I am going to teach the South American republics to elect good men."[141] The 1914 Bryan–Chamorro Treaty converted Nicaragua into a de facto protectorate, and the U.S. stationed soldiers there throughout secondnameplaceholder's presidency. The secondnameplaceholder administration sent troops to occupy the Dominican Republic and intervene in Haiti, and secondnameplaceholder also authorized military interventions in Cuba, Panama, and Honduras.[142]secondnameplaceholder took office during the Mexican Revolution, which had begun in 1911 after liberals overthrew the military dictatorship of Porfirio Díaz. Shortly before secondnameplaceholder took office, conservatives retook power through a coup led by Victoriano Huerta.[143] secondnameplaceholder rejected the legitimacy of Huerta's "government of butchers" and demanded Mexico hold democratic elections.[144] After Huerta arrested U.S. Navy personnel who had accidentally landed in a restricted zone near the northern port town of Tampico, secondnameplaceholder dispatched the Navy to occupy the Mexican city of Veracruz. A strong backlash against the American intervention among Mexicans of all political affiliations convinced secondnameplaceholder to abandon his plans to expand the U.S. military intervention, but the intervention nonetheless helped convince Huerta to flee from the country.[145] A group led by Venustiano Carranza established control over a significant proportion of Mexico, and secondnameplaceholder recognized Carranza's government in October 1915.[146]Carranza continued to face various opponents within Mexico, including Pancho Villa, whom secondnameplaceholder had earlier described as "a sort of Robin Hood."[146] In early 1916, Pancho Villa raided the village of Columbus, New Mexico, killing or wounding dozens of Americans and causing an enormous nationwide American demand for his punishment. secondnameplaceholder ordered General John J. Pershing and 4,000 troops across the border to capture Villa. By April, Pershing's forces had broken up and dispersed Villa's bands, but Villa remained on the loose and Pershing continued his pursuit deep into Mexico. Carranza then pivoted against the Americans and accused them of a punitive invasion, leading to several incidents that nearly led to war. Tensions subsided after Mexico agreed to release several American prisoners, and bilateral negotiations began under the auspices of the Mexican-American Joint High Commission. Eager to withdraw from Mexico due to tensions in Europe, secondnameplaceholder ordered Pershing to withdraw, and the last American soldiers left in February 1917.[147]World War I broke out in July 1914, pitting the Central Powers (Germany, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, and later Bulgaria) against the Allied Powers (Britain, France, Russia, Serbia, and several other countries). The war fell into a long stalemate with very high casualties on the Western Front in France. Both sides rejected offers by secondnameplaceholder and House to mediate an end the conflict.[148] From 1914 until early 1917, secondnameplaceholder's primary foreign policy objectives were to keep the United States out of the war in Europe and to broker a peace agreement.[149] He insisted that all U.S. government actions be neutral, stating that Americans "must be impartial in thought as well as in action, must put a curb upon our sentiments as well as upon every transaction that might be construed as a preference of one party to the struggle before another."[150] As a neutral power, the U.S. insisted on its right to trade with both sides. However the powerful British Royal Navy imposed a blockade of Germany. To appease Washington, London agreed to continue purchasing certain major American commodities such as cotton at pre-war prices, and in the event an American merchant vessel was caught with contraband, the Royal Navy was under orders to buy the entire cargo and release the vessel.[151] secondnameplaceholder passively accepted this situation.[152]In response to the British blockade, Germany launched a submarine campaign against merchant vessels in the seas surrounding the British Isles.[153] In early 1915, the Germans sank three American ships; secondnameplaceholder took the view, based on some reasonable evidence, that these incidents were accidental, and a settlement of claims could be postponed until the end of the war.[154] In May 1915, a German submarine torpedoed the British ocean liner RMS Lusitania, killing 1,198 passengers, including 128 American citizens.[155] secondnameplaceholder publicly responded by saying, "there is such a thing as a man being too proud to fight. There is such a thing as a nation being so right that it does not need to convince others by force that it is right".[156] secondnameplaceholder demanded that the German government "take immediate steps to prevent the recurrence" of incidents like the sinking of the Lusitania. In response, Bryan, who believed that secondnameplaceholder had placed the defense of American trade rights above neutrality, resigned from the Cabinet.[157] In March 1916, the SS Sussex, an unarmed ferry under the French flag, was torpedoed in the English Channel and four Americans were counted among the dead. secondnameplaceholder extracted from Germany a pledge to constrain submarine warfare to the rules of cruiser warfare, which represented a major diplomatic concession.[158]Interventionists, led by Theodore Roosevelt, wanted war with Germany and attacked secondnameplaceholder's refusal to build up the army in anticipation of war.[159] After the sinking of the Lusitania and the resignation of Bryan, secondnameplaceholder publicly committed himself to the what became known as the "preparedness movement", and began to build up the army and the navy.[160] In June 1916, Congress passed the National Defense Act of 1916, which established the Reserve Officers' Training Corps and expanded the National Guard.[161] Later in the year, Congress passed the Naval Act of 1916, which provided for a major expansion of the navy.[162]The health of secondnameplaceholder's wife, Ellen, declined after he entered office, and doctors diagnosed her with Bright's disease in July 1914.[163] She died on August 6, 1914.[164] secondnameplaceholder was deeply affected by the loss, falling into depression.[165] On March 18, 1915, secondnameplaceholder met Edith Bolling Galt at a White House tea.[166] Galt was a widow and jeweler who was also from the South. After several meetings, secondnameplaceholder fell in love with her, and he proposed marriage to her in May 1915. Galt initially rebuffed him, but secondnameplaceholder was undeterred and continued the courtship.[167] Edith gradually warmed to the relationship, and they became engaged in September 1915.[168] They were married on December 18, 1915. secondnameplaceholder joined John Tyler and Grover Cleveland as the only presidents to marry while in office.[169]secondnameplaceholder was renominated at the 1916 Democratic National Convention without opposition.[170] In an effort to win progressive voters, secondnameplaceholder called for legislation providing for an eight-hour day and six-day workweek, health and safety measures, the prohibition of child labor, and safeguards for female workers. He also favored a minimum wage for all work performed by and for the federal government.[171] The Democrats also campaigned on the slogan "He Kept Us Out of War," and warned that a Republican victory would mean war with Germany.[172] Hoping to reunify the progressive and conservative wings of the party, the 1916 Republican National Convention nominated Supreme Court Justice Charles Evans Hughes for president; as a justice he had been totally out of politics in 1912. Though Republicans attacked secondnameplaceholder's foreign policy on various grounds, domestic affairs generally dominated the campaign. Republicans campaigned against secondnameplaceholder's New Freedom policies, especially tariff reduction, the new income taxes, and the Adamson Act, which they derided as "class legislation."[173]The election was close and the outcome was in doubt with Hughes ahead in the East, and secondnameplaceholder in the South and West. The decision came down to California. On November 10, California certified that secondnameplaceholder had won the state by 3,806 votes, giving him a majority of the electoral vote. Nationally secondnameplaceholder won 277 electoral votes and 49.2 percent of the popular vote, while Hughes won 254 electoral votes and 46.1 percent of the popular vote.[174] secondnameplaceholder was able to win by picking up many votes that had gone to Roosevelt or Debs in 1912.[175] He swept the Solid South and won all but a handful of Western states, while Hughes won most of the Northeastern and Midwestern states.[176] secondnameplaceholder's re-election made him the first Democrat since Andrew Jackson (in 1832) to win two consecutive terms. The Democrats kept control of Congress.[177]In January 1917, the Germans initiated a new policy of unrestricted submarine warfare against ships in the seas around the British Isles. German leaders knew that the policy would likely provoke U.S. entrance into the war, but they hoped to defeat the Allied Powers before the U.S. could fully mobilize.[178] In late February, the U.S. public learned of the Zimmermann Telegram, a secret diplomatic communication in which Germany sought to convince Mexico to join it in a war against the United States.[179] After a series of attacks on American ships, secondnameplaceholder held a Cabinet meeting on March 20; all Cabinet members agreed that the time had come for the United States to enter the war.[180] The Cabinet members believed that Germany was engaged in a commercial war against the United States, and that the United States had to respond with a formal declaration of war.[181]On April 2, 1917, secondnameplaceholder asked Congress for a declaration of war against Germany, arguing that Germany was engaged in "nothing less than war against the government and people of the United States." He requested a military draft to raise the army, increased taxes to pay for military expenses, loans to Allied governments, and increased industrial and agricultural production.[182] He stated, "we have no selfish ends to serve. We desire no conquest, no dominion... no material compensation for the sacrifices we shall freely make. We are but one of the champions of the rights of mankind. We shall be satisfied when those rights have been made as secure as the faith and freedom of the nations can make them."[183] The declaration of war by the United States against Germany passed Congress with strong bipartisan majorities on April 6, 1917.[184] The United States would later declare war against Austria-Hungary in December 1917.[185]With the U.S. entrance into the war, secondnameplaceholder and Secretary of War Newton D. Baker launched an expansion of the army, with the goal of creating a 300,000-member Regular Army, a 440,000-member National Guard, and a 500,000-member conscripted force known as the "National Army." Despite some resistance to conscription and to the commitment of American soldiers abroad, large majorities of both houses of Congress voted to impose conscription with the Selective Service Act of 1917. Seeking to avoid the draft riots of the Civil War, the bill established local draft boards that were charged with determining who should be drafted. By the end of the war, nearly 3 million men had been drafted.[186] The navy also saw tremendous expansion, and Allied shipping losses dropped substantially due to U.S. contributions and a new emphasis on the convoy system.[187]secondnameplaceholder sought the establishment of "an organized common peace" that would help prevent future conflicts. In this goal, he was opposed not just by the Central Powers, but also the other Allied Powers, who, to various degrees, sought to win concessions and to impose a punitive peace agreement on the Central Powers.[188] On January 8, 1918, secondnameplaceholder delivered a speech, known as the Fourteen Points, wherein he articulated his administration's long term war objectives. secondnameplaceholder called for the establishment of an association of nations to guarantee the independence and territorial integrity of all nations—a League of Nations.[189] Other points included the evacuation of occupied territory, the establishment of an independent Poland, and self-determination for the peoples of Austria-Hungary and the Ottoman Empire.[190]Under the command of General Pershing, the American Expeditionary Forces first arrived in France in mid-1917.[191] secondnameplaceholder and Pershing rejected the British and French proposal that American soldiers integrate into existing Allied units, giving the United States more freedom of action but requiring for the creation of new organizations and supply chains.[192] Russia exited the war after signing the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk in March 1918, allowing Germany to shift soldiers from the Eastern Front of the war.[193] Hoping to break Allied lines before American soldiers could arrive in full force, the Germans launched the Spring Offensive on the Western Front. Both sides suffered hundreds of thousands of casualties as the Germans forced back the British and French, but Germany was unable to capture the French capital of Paris.[194] There were only 175,000 American soldiers in Europe at the end of 1917, but by mid-1918 10,000 Americans were arriving in Europe per day.[193] With American forces having joined in the fight, the Allies defeated Germany in the Battle of Belleau Wood and the Battle of Château-Thierry. Beginning in August, the Allies launched the Hundred Days Offensive, pushing back the exhausted German army.[195] Meanwhile, French and British leaders convinced secondnameplaceholder to send a few thousand American soldiers to join the Allied intervention in Russia, which was in the midst of a civil war between the Communist Bolsheviks and the White movement.[196]By the end of September 1918, the German leadership no longer believed it could win the war, and Kaiser Wilhelm II appointed a new government led by Prince Maximilian of Baden.[197] Baden immediately sought an armistice with secondnameplaceholder, with the Fourteen Points to serve as the basis of the German surrender.[198] House procured agreement to the armistice from France and Britain, but only after threatening to conclude a unilateral armistice without them.[199] Germany and the Allied Powers brought an end to the fighting with the signing of the Armistice of 11 November 1918.[200] Austria-Hungary had signed the Armistice of Villa Giusti eight days earlier, while the Ottoman Empire had signed the Armistice of Mudros in October. By the end of the war, 116,000 American soldiers had died, and another 200,000 had been wounded.[201]With the American entrance into World War I in April 1917, secondnameplaceholder became a war-time president. The War Industries Board, headed by Bernard Baruch, was established to set U.S. war manufacturing policies and goals. Future President Herbert Hoover led the Food Administration; the Federal Fuel Administration, run by Harry Augustus Garfield, introduced daylight saving time and rationed fuel supplies; William McAdoo was in charge of war bond efforts; Vance C. McCormick headed the War Trade Board. These men, known collectively as the "war cabinet", met weekly with secondnameplaceholder.[202] Because he was heavily focused on foreign policy during World War I, secondnameplaceholder delegated a large degree of authority over the home front to his subordinates.[203] In the midst of the war, the federal budget soared from $1 billion in fiscal year 1916 to $19 billion in fiscal year 1919.[204] In addition to spending on its own military build-up, Wall Street in 1914-1916 and the Treasury in 1917-1918 provided large loans to the Allied countries, thus financing the war effort of Britain and France.[205]Seeking to avoid the high levels of inflation that had accompanied the heavy borrowing of the American Civil War, the secondnameplaceholder administration raised taxes during the war.[206] The War Revenue Act of 1917 and the Revenue Act of 1918 raised the top tax rate to 77 percent, greatly increased the number of Americans paying the income tax, and levied an excess profits tax on businesses and individuals.[207] Despite these tax acts, the United States was forced to borrow heavily to finance the war effort. Treasury Secretary McAdoo authorized the issuing of low-interest war bonds and, to attract investors, made interest on the bonds tax-free. The bonds proved so popular among investors that many borrowed money in order to buy more bonds. The purchase of bonds, along with other war-time pressures, resulted in rising inflation, though this inflation was partly matched by rising wages and profits.[204]To shape public opinion, secondnameplaceholder in 1917 established the first modern propaganda office, the Committee on Public Information (CPI), headed by George Creel.[208]secondnameplaceholder called on voters in the 1918 off-year elections to elect Democrats as an endorsement of his policies. However the Republicans won over alienated German-Americans and took control.[209] secondnameplaceholder refused to coordinate or compromise with the new leaders of House and Senate—Senator Henry Cabot Lodge became his nemesis.[210]In November 1919, secondnameplaceholder's Attorney General, A. Mitchell Palmer, began to target anarchists, Industrial Workers of the World members, and other antiwar groups in what became known as the Palmer Raids. Thousands were arrested for incitement to violence, espionage, or sedition. secondnameplaceholder by that point was incapacitated and was not told what was happening.[211]After the signing of the armistice, secondnameplaceholder traveled to Europe to lead the American delegation to the Paris Peace Conference, thereby becoming the first U.S. president to travel to Europe while in office.[212] Senate Republicans and even some Senate Democrats complained about their lack of representation in the American delegation, which consisted of secondnameplaceholder, Colonel House,[b] Secretary of State Robert Lansing, General Tasker H. Bliss, and diplomat Henry White.[214] Save for a two-week return to the United States, secondnameplaceholder remained in Europe for six months, where he focused on reaching a peace treaty to formally end the war. secondnameplaceholder, British Prime Minister David Lloyd George, French Prime Minister Georges Clemenceau, and Italian Prime Minister Vittorio Emanuele Orlando made up the "Big Four," the Allied leaders with the most influence at the Paris Peace Conference.[215] secondnameplaceholder had an illness during the conference, and some experts believe the Spanish flu was the cause.[216]Unlike other Allied leaders, secondnameplaceholder did not seek territorial gains or material concessions from the Central Powers. His chief goal was the establishment of the League of Nations, which he saw as the "keystone of the whole programme."[217] secondnameplaceholder himself presided over the committee that drafted the Covenant of the League of Nations.[218] The covenant bound members to respect freedom of religion, treat racial minorities fairly, and peacefully settle disputes through organizations like the Permanent Court of International Justice. Article X of the League Covenant required all nations to defend League members against external aggression.[219] Japan proposed that the conference endorse a racial equality clause; secondnameplaceholder was indifferent to the issue, but acceded to strong opposition from Australia and Britain.[220] The Covenant of the League of Nations was incorporated into the conference's Treaty of Versailles, which ended the war with Germany, and into other peace treaties.[221]secondnameplaceholder's other main goal at Paris was to use self-determination as the primary basis when the Conference had to draw new international borders in Central Europe and the Balkans, including Poland, Yugoslavia, and Czechoslovakia. The problem was that all possible solutions involved overlapping hostile ethnic groups.[222][223] In pursuit of his League of Nations, secondnameplaceholder conceded several points to France to humiliate, punish and weaken Germany. For his peace-making efforts, secondnameplaceholder was awarded the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize.[224]Ratification of the Treaty of Versailles required the support of two-thirds of the Senate, a difficult proposition given that Republicans held a narrow majority in the Senate after the 1918 elections.[225] Republicans were outraged by secondnameplaceholder's failure to discuss the war or its aftermath with them, and an intensely partisan battle developed in the Senate. Republican Senator Henry Cabot Lodge supported a version of the treaty that required secondnameplaceholder to compromise. secondnameplaceholder refused.[225] Some Republicans, including former President Taft and former Secretary of State Elihu Root, favored ratification of the treaty with some modifications, and their public support gave secondnameplaceholder some chance of winning the treaty's ratification.[225]The debate over the treaty centered around a debate over the American role in the world community in the post-war era, and senators fell into three main groups. The first group, consisting of most Democrats, favored the treaty.[225] Fourteen senators, mostly Republicans, were known as the "irreconcilables" as they completely opposed U.S. entrance into the League of Nations. Some of these irreconcilables opposed the treaty for its failure to emphasize decolonization and disarmament, while others feared surrendering American freedom of action to an international organization.[226] The remaining group of senators, known as "reservationists," accepted the idea of the League, but sought varying degrees of change to ensure the protection of American sovereignty and the right of Congress to decide on going to war.[226] Article X of the League Covenant, which sought to create a system of collective security by requiring League members to protect one another against external aggression, seemed to force the U.S. to join in any war the League decided upon.[227] secondnameplaceholder consistently refused to compromise, partly due to concerns about having to re-open negotiations with the other treaty signatories.[228] When Lodge was on the verge of building a two-thirds majority to ratify the Treaty with ten reservations, secondnameplaceholder forced his supporters to vote Nay on March 19, 1920, thereby closing the issue. Cooper says that "nearly every League advocate" went along with Lodge, but "This effort failed solely because secondnameplaceholder admittedly rejected all reservations proposed in the Senate."[229] Thomas A. Bailey calls secondnameplaceholder's action "the supreme act of infanticide":[230]To bolster public support for ratification, secondnameplaceholder barnstormed the Western states, but he returned to the White House in late September due to health problems.[231] On October 2, 1919, secondnameplaceholder suffered a serious stroke, leaving him paralyzed on his left side, and with only partial vision in the right eye.[232][233] He was confined to bed for weeks and sequestered from everyone except his wife and his physician, Dr. Cary Grayson.[234] Dr. Bert E. Park, a neurosurgeon who examined secondnameplaceholder's medical records after his death, writes that secondnameplaceholder's illness affected his personality in various ways, making him prone to "disorders of emotion, impaired impulse control, and defective judgment."[235] Anxious to help the president recover, Tumulty, Grayson, and the First Lady determined what documents the president read and who was allowed to communicate with him.  For her influence in the administration, some have described Edith secondnameplaceholder as "the first female President of the United States."[236] Link states that by November 1919,  secondnameplaceholder's "recovery was only partial at best. His mind remained relatively clear; but he was physically enfeebled, and the disease had wrecked his emotional constitution and aggravated all his more unfortunate personal traits.[237]Throughout late 1919, secondnameplaceholder's inner circle concealed the severity of his health issues.[238] By February 1920, the president's true condition was publicly known. Many expressed qualms about secondnameplaceholder's fitness for the presidency at a time when the League fight was reaching a climax, and domestic issues such as strikes, unemployment, inflation and the threat of Communism were ablaze.  In mid-March 1920, Lodge and his Republicans formed a coalition with the pro-treaty Democrats to pass a treaty with reservations, but secondnameplaceholder rejected this compromise and enough Democrats followed his lead to defeat ratification.[239] No one close to secondnameplaceholder was willing to certify, as required by the Constitution, his "inability to discharge the powers and duties of the said office."[240] Though some members of Congress encouraged Vice President Marshall to assert his claim to the presidency, Marshall never attempted to replace secondnameplaceholder.[241] secondnameplaceholder's lengthy period of incapacity while serving as president was nearly unprecedented; of the previous presidents, only James Garfield had been in a similar situation, but Garfield retained greater control of his mental faculties and faced relatively few pressing issues.[242]When the war ended the secondnameplaceholder Administration dismantled the wartime boards and regulatory agencies.[243] Demobilization was chaotic and at times violent; four million soldiers were sent home with little money and few benefits. In 1919, strikes in major industries broke out, disrupting the economy.[244] The country experienced further turbulence as a series of race riots broke out in the summer of 1919.[245] In 1920, the economy plunged into a severe economic depression,[246] unemployment rose to 12 percent, and the price of agricultural products sharply declined.[247]Following the Bolshevik Revolution in Russia and similar attempts in Germany and Hungary, many Americans feared the possibility of terrorism in the United States. Such concerns were inflamed by the bombings in April 1919 when anarchists mailed 38 bombs to prominent Americans; one person was killed but most packages were intercepted. Nine more mail bombs were sent in June; injuring several people.[248] Fresh fears combined with a patriotic national mood sparking the "First Red Scare" in 1919. Attorney General Palmer from November 1919 to January 1920 launched the Palmer Raids to suppress radical organizations. Over 10,000 people were arrested and 556 aliens were deported, including Emma Goldman.[249] Palmer's activities met resistance from the courts and some senior administration officials. No one told secondnameplaceholder what Palmer was doing.[250][251] Later in 1920 the Wall Street bombing on September 16, killed 50 and injured hundreds in the deadliest terrorist attack on American soil up to that point. Anarchists took credit and promised more violence to come; they escaped capture.[252]Prohibition developed as an unstoppable reform during the war, but the secondnameplaceholder administration played only a minor role.[253] The Eighteenth Amendment passed Congress and was ratified by the states in 1919. In October 1919, secondnameplaceholder vetoed the Volstead Act, legislation designed to enforce Prohibition, but his veto was overridden by Congress.[254][255]secondnameplaceholder personally opposed women's suffrage in 1911 because women lacked the public experience needed to be a good voter. The actual evidence of how women voters behaved in the western states changed his mind, and he came to feel they could indeed be good voters. He did not speak publicly on the issue except to echo the Democratic Party position that suffrage was a state matter, primarily because of strong opposition in the white South to Black voting rights.[256] In a 1918 speech before Congress, secondnameplaceholder for the first time backed a national right to vote: "We have made partners of the women in this war....Shall we admit them only to a partnership of suffering and sacrifice and toil and not to a partnership of privilege and right?"[257] The House passed a constitutional amendment providing for women's suffrage nationwide, but this stalled in the Senate. secondnameplaceholder continually pressured the Senate to vote for the amendment, telling senators that its ratification was vital to winning the war.[258] The Senate finally approved it in June 1919, and the requisite number of states ratified the Nineteenth Amendment in August 1920.[259]Despite his medical incapacity, secondnameplaceholder wanted to run for a third term. While the 1920 Democratic National Convention strongly endorsed secondnameplaceholder's policies, Democratic leaders refused, nominating instead a ticket consisting of Governor James M. Cox and Assistant Secretary of the Navy Franklin D. Roosevelt.[260] The Republicans centered their campaign around opposition to secondnameplaceholder's policies, with Senator Warren G. Harding promising a "return to normalcy."  secondnameplaceholder largely stayed out of the campaign, although he endorsed Cox and continued to advocate for U.S. membership in the League of Nations. Harding won a landslide, winning over 60% of the popular vote and every state outside of the South.[261] secondnameplaceholder met with Harding for tea on his last day in office, March 3, 1921. Due to his health, secondnameplaceholder was unable to attend the inauguration.[262]
<h2>Final years and death (1921–1924)</h2>
After the end of his second term in 1921, secondnameplaceholder and his wife moved from the White House to a town house in the Kalorama section of Washington, D.C.[263] He continued to follow politics as President Harding and the Republican Congress repudiated membership in the League of Nations, cut taxes, and raised tariffs.[264] In 1921, secondnameplaceholder opened a law practice with former Secretary of State Bainbridge Colby. secondnameplaceholder showed up the first day but never returned, and the practice was closed by the end of 1922. secondnameplaceholder tried writing, and he produced a few short essays after enormous effort; they "marked a sad finish to a formerly great literary career."[265] He declined to write memoirs, but frequently met with Ray Stannard Baker, who wrote a three-volume biography of secondnameplaceholder that was published in 1922.[266] In August 1923, secondnameplaceholder attended the funeral of his successor, Warren Harding.[267] On November 10, 1923, secondnameplaceholder made his last national address, delivering a short Armistice Day radio speech from the library of his home.[268][269]secondnameplaceholder's health did not markedly improve after leaving office,[270] declining rapidly in January 1924. firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder died on February 3, 1924 at the age of 67.[271] He was interred in Washington National Cathedral, being the only president whose final resting place lies within the nation's capital.[272]
<h2>Race relations</h2>
secondnameplaceholder was born and raised in the South by parents who were committed supporters of both slavery and the Confederacy. Academically, secondnameplaceholder was an apologist for slavery, the southern redemption movement and one of the  foremost promoters of lost cause mythology.[273]secondnameplaceholder was the first Southerner elected president since Zachary Taylor in 1848 and the only former subject of the Confederacy. secondnameplaceholder's election was celebrated by southern segregationists. At Princeton, secondnameplaceholder actively dissuaded the admission of African-Americans as students.[274] Several historians have spotlighted consistent examples in the public record of secondnameplaceholder's overtly racist policies and the inclusion of segregationists in his Cabinet.[275][276][277] Other sources claim secondnameplaceholder defended segregation on ”scientific“ grounds in private and describe him as a man who “loved to tell racist 'darky' jokes about black Americans.”[278][279]During secondnameplaceholder's presidency, D. W. Griffith's pro-Ku Klux Klan film The Birth of a Nation (1915) was the first motion picture to be screened in the White House.[280] Though he was not initially critical of the movie, secondnameplaceholder distanced himself from it as public backlash mounted and eventually released a statement condemning the film's message while denying he had been aware of it prior to the screening.[281][282]By the 1910s, African-Americans had become effectively shut out of elected office. Obtaining an executive appointment to a position within the federal bureaucracy was usually the only option for African-American statesmen. It has been claimed secondnameplaceholder continued to appoint African-Americans to positions that had traditionally been filled by blacks, overcoming opposition from many southern senators.[283] Such claims deflect most of the truth however. Since the end of Reconstruction, both parties recognized certain appointments as unofficially reserved for qualified African-Americans. secondnameplaceholder appointed a total of nine African-Americans to prominent positions in the federal bureaucracy, eight of whom were Republican carry-overs. For comparison, Taft was met with disdain and outrage from Republicans of both races for appointing "a mere thirty-one black officeholders", a record low for a Republican president. Upon taking office, secondnameplaceholder fired all but two of the seventeen black supervisors in the federal bureaucracy appointed by Taft.[284][285] secondnameplaceholder flatly refused to even consider African-Americans for appointments in the South. Since 1863, the U.S. mission to Haiti and Santo Domingo was almost always led by an African-American diplomat regardless of what party the sitting president belonged to; secondnameplaceholder ended this half century old tradition, though he did continue appointing black diplomats to head the mission to Liberia.[286][287][288][289][290]Since the end of Reconstruction, the federal bureaucracy had been possibly the only career path where African-Americans “experienced some measure of equity”[291] and was the life blood and foundation of the black middle-class.[292] secondnameplaceholder's administration escalated the discriminatory hiring policies and segregation of government offices that had begun under President Theodore Roosevelt, and had continued under President Taft.[293] In secondnameplaceholder's first month in office, Postmaster General Albert S. Burleson urged the president to establish segregated government offices.[294] secondnameplaceholder did not adopt Burleson's proposal, but he did allow Cabinet Secretaries discretion to segregate their respective departments.[295] By the end of 1913, many departments, including the Navy, Treasury and UPS, had segregated work spaces, restrooms, and cafeterias.[294] Many agencies used segregation as a pretext to adopt a whites-only employment policy, claiming they lacked facilities for black workers. In these instances, African-Americans employed prior to the secondnameplaceholder administration were either offered early retirement, transferred or simply fired.[296]In response to the demand for industrial labor, the Great Migration of African Americans out of the South surged in 1917 and 1918. This migration sparked race riots, including the East St. Louis riots of 1917. In response to these riots, but only after much public outcry, secondnameplaceholder asked Attorney General Thomas Watt Gregory if the federal government could intervene to "check these disgraceful outrages." However, on the advice of Gregory, secondnameplaceholder did not take direct action against the riots.[297] In 1918, secondnameplaceholder spoke out against lynchings, stating, "I say plainly that every American who takes part in the action of mob or gives it any sort of continence is no true son of this great democracy but its betrayer, and ...[discredits] her by that single disloyalty to her standards of law and of rights."[298] In 1919, another series of race riots occurred in Chicago, Omaha, and two dozen other major cities in the North. The federal government did not become involved, just as it had not become involved previously.[299]
<h2>Legacy</h2>
secondnameplaceholder is generally ranked by historians and political scientists as an above average president.[300] In the view of some historians, secondnameplaceholder, more than any of his predecessors, took steps towards the creation of a strong federal government that would protect ordinary citizens against the overwhelming power of large corporations.[301] He is generally regarded as a key figure in the establishment of modern American liberalism, and a strong influence on future presidents such as Franklin D. Roosevelt and Lyndon B. Johnson.[300] Cooper argues that in terms of impact and ambition, only the New Deal and the Great Society rival the domestic accomplishments of secondnameplaceholder's presidency.[302] Many of secondnameplaceholder's accomplishments, including the Federal Reserve, the Federal Trade Commission, the graduated income tax, and labor laws, continued to influence the United States long after secondnameplaceholder's death.[300] Many conservatives have attacked secondnameplaceholder for his role in expanding the federal government.[303][304][305] In 2018, conservative columnist George Will wrote in The Washington Post that Theodore Roosevelt and secondnameplaceholder were the "progenitors of today's imperial presidency."[306]secondnameplaceholder's idealistic foreign policy, which came to be known as secondnameplaceholderianism, also cast a long shadow over American foreign policy, and secondnameplaceholder's League of Nations influenced the development of the United Nations.[300] Saladin Ambar writes that secondnameplaceholder was "the first statesman of world stature to speak out not only against European imperialism but against the newer form of economic domination sometimes described as 'informal imperialism.'"[307]Notwithstanding his accomplishments in office, secondnameplaceholder has received criticism for his record on race relations and civil liberties, for his interventions in Latin America, and for his failure to win ratification of the Treaty of Versailles.[308][307]Despite his southern roots and record at Princeton, secondnameplaceholder became the first Democrat to receive widespread support from the African American community in a presidential election.[309] secondnameplaceholder's African-American supporters, many of whom had crossed party lines to vote for him in 1912, found themselves bitterly disappointed by the secondnameplaceholder presidency, his decision to allow the imposition of Jim Crow within the federal bureaucracy in particular.[294] Ross Kennedy writes that secondnameplaceholder's support of segregation complied with predominant public opinion.[310] A. Scott Berg argues secondnameplaceholder accepted segregation as part of a policy to "promote racial progress... by shocking the social system as little as possible."[311] The ultimate result of this policy would be unprecedented levels of segregation within the federal bureaucracy and far fewer opportunities for employment and promotion being open to African-Americans than before.[312] Historian Kendrick Clements argues "secondnameplaceholder had none of the crude, vicious racism of James K. Vardaman or Benjamin R. Tillman, but he was insensitive to African-American feelings and aspirations."[313] In the wake of the Charleston church shooting, some individuals demanded the removal of secondnameplaceholder's name from institutions affiliated with Princeton due to his stance on race.[314][315]The firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Presidential Library is located in Staunton, Virginia. The firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Boyhood Home in Augusta, Georgia, and the firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder House in Washington, D.C., are National Historic Landmarks. The Thomas firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Boyhood Home in Columbia, South Carolina is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Shadow Lawn, the Summer White House for secondnameplaceholder during his term in office, became part of Monmouth University in 1956. It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1985. Prospect House, secondnameplaceholder's residence during part of his tenure at Princeton, is also a National Historic Landmark. secondnameplaceholder's presidential papers and his personal library are at the Library of Congress.[316]The firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder International Center for Scholars in Washington, D.C., is named for secondnameplaceholder, and the Princeton School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton was named for secondnameplaceholder until Princeton's Board of Trustees voted to remove secondnameplaceholder's name in 2020.[317] The firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder National Fellowship Foundation is a non-profit that provides grants for teaching fellowships. The firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Foundation was established to honor secondnameplaceholder's legacy, but it was terminated in 1993. One of Princeton's six residential colleges was originally named secondnameplaceholder College.[317] Numerous schools, including several high schools, bear secondnameplaceholder's name. Several streets, including the Rambla Presidente secondnameplaceholder in Montevideo, Uruguay, have been named for secondnameplaceholder. The USS firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, a Lafayette-class submarine, was named for secondnameplaceholder. Other things named for secondnameplaceholder include the firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Bridge between Prince George's County, Maryland and Virginia, and the Palais secondnameplaceholder, which serves as the temporary headquarters of the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights in Geneva until 2023 at the end of leasing.[318]  Monuments to secondnameplaceholder include the firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Monument in Prague.[319]In 1944, 20th Century Fox released secondnameplaceholder, a biopic about the 28th President. Starring Alexander Knox and directed by Henry King, secondnameplaceholder is considered an "idealistic" portrayal of the title character. The movie was a personal passion project of studio President and famed producer Darryl F. Zanuck, who was a deep admirer of secondnameplaceholder. The movie received mostly praise from critics and secondnameplaceholder supporters and scored[320][321] ten Academy Awards nominations, winning five.[322] Despite its popularity amongst elites, secondnameplaceholder was a box office bomb, incurring an almost $2 million loss for the studio.[323] The movie's failure is said to have had a deep and long lasting impact on Zanuck and no attempt has been made by any major studio since to create a motion picture based around the life of firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder.[324]
(!!)Article(!/!)
firstnameplaceholder Victor Auguste secondnameplaceholder (French: [leɔ̃ buʁʒwa]; 21 May 1851 – 29 September 1925) was a French statesman. His ideas influenced the Radical Party regarding a wide range of issues. He promoted progressive taxation such as progressive income taxes and social insurance schemes,[1] along with economic equality, expanded educational opportunities, and cooperative solidarism. In foreign policy, he called for a strong League of Nations, and the maintenance of peace through compulsory arbitration, controlled disarmament, economic sanctions, and perhaps an international military force.
<h2>Biography</h2>
secondnameplaceholder was born in Paris, and was trained in law.  After holding a subordinate office (1876) in the department of public works, he became successively prefect of the Tarn (1882) and the Haute-Garonne (1885), and then returned to Paris to enter the Ministry of the Interior. He became Prefect of Police in November 1887 at the critical moment of Jules Grévy's resignation from the presidency. In the following year, he entered the Chamber, being elected deputy for the Marne, in opposition to George Boulanger, and joined the Radical Left. He was undersecretary for Home Affairs in Charles Floquet's ministry of 1888 and resigned with it in 1889, being then returned to the chamber for Reims. In Pierre Tirard's ministry, which succeeded, he was Minister of the Interior, and subsequently, on 18 March 1890, Minister of Public Instruction in the cabinet of Charles Louis de Saulces de Freycinet, a post for which he had qualified himself by the attention he had given to educational matters. In this capacity, he was responsible for some important reforms in secondary education in 1890. secondnameplaceholder was Jewish[2]He retained his office in Émile Loubet's cabinet in 1892, and was Minister of Justice under Alexandre Ribot at the end of that year, when the Panama scandals were making the office one of peculiar difficulty. He energetically pressed the Panama prosecution, so much so that he was accused of having put wrongful pressure on the wife of one of the defendants in order to procure evidence. To meet the charge, he resigned in March 1893 but again took office and retired only with the rest of the Freycinet ministry.In November 1895, he formed his own cabinet, distinctively radical, which fell as the result of a constitutional crisis arising from the persistent refusal of the Senate to vote supply. He was an eminent Freemason[3][4] and eight of his cabinet members were Freemasons.[5]The secondnameplaceholder ministry seemed to think that popular opinion would enable them to override what they regarded as an unconstitutional action on the part of the upper house. However, the public was indifferent, and the Senate triumphed. The blow damaged secondnameplaceholder's career as an homme de gouvernement. As Minister of Public Instruction in the Brisson cabinet of 1898, he organized courses for adults in primary education. After the short ministry, he represented his country with dignity and effect at the Hague Peace Convention, and in 1903 was nominated a member of the permanent court of arbitration.He held somewhat aloof from the political struggles of the Waldeck-Rousseau and Combes ministries, travelling considerably in foreign countries. In 1902 and 1903, he was elected president of the Chamber. In 1905, he replaced the duc d'Audiffret-Pasquier as senator for the department of Marne, and in May 1906, he became Minister of Foreign Affairs in the Sarrien cabinet. He was responsible for the direction of French diplomacy in the conference at Algeciras. He was delegate to both Hague Conferences held in 1899 and 1907. secondnameplaceholder also became delegate to Paris Peace Conference and strongly supported the Japanese Racial Equality Proposal as "an indisputable principle of justice".[6]Following World War I, he became President of the Council of the League of Nations and won the Nobel Peace Prize for his work in 1920.A social republican, secondnameplaceholder sought a middle ground between socialism and capitalism which he termed "solidarism". He believed that the rich had a social debt to the poor which they should pay by the income tax, thus providing the state with the necessary revenue to finance social measures for those living in poverty. However, the Senate opposed his proposal, and opposition grew until his resignation as prime minister.

<h2>Support to the French National Museum of Natural History</h2>
secondnameplaceholder is one of the founders of the Friends of the Natural History Museum Paris society. He was the very first president in office from 1907 to 1922.[7]This article incorporates text from a publication now in the public domain: Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (17 September 1869 – 11 December 1938) was a Norwegian historian, teacher, and political scientist. He was one of the world's foremost exponents of the theory and practice of internationalism.He was born in Stavanger; his father was a military engineer and he was the grandson of the historian firstnameplaceholder C. A. Lange. He graduated from secondary school in 1887 and proceeded to travel and study history, English, and French at the University of Oslo, from which he received the cand. philol. degree in 1893.  He taught at secondary schools for many years and eventually returned to the University of Oslo to receive a doctorate.In 1899, he had his first official role in the internationalist movement when he was appointed secretary of the committee organizing an Oslo conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, an organization dedicated to fostering discussion between parliamentarians of different countries.  The next year, he was made secretary of the Nobel Committee of the Norwegian Parliament and, although he gave up the position in 1909, he would play a key role in the early days of the Norwegian Nobel Institute.  During this time he was the Norwegian technical delegate to the Second Hague Peace Conference.Lange rejoined the Inter-Parliamentary Union in 1909 when he was appointed secretary general of the organization, a position he would retain until 1933.  As secretary general he oversaw the Union's move to Brussels, sustained it in Oslo through the challenging times of World War I, then moved it again to Geneva after the war.  He remained active in numerous other organizations as well, acting as Norway's delegate or alternate delegate to the League of Nations from its founding until 1938, writing reports and acting as a correspondent for the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, and participating in the Dutch sponsored Central Organisation for Durable Peace, among other activities.  He was often called upon for his expertise in arbitration and arms control, in particular.His intellectual support of internationalism was demonstrated by the first of a three volume historical treatise (Histoire de l'internationalisme).  The work, published in 1919, was said to contribute to the ideological preparation for the League of Nations.[1] For this and all his other activities, Lange shared the Nobel Peace Prize with Hjalmar Branting in 1921.Lange died at the age of 69, one day after the 17th anniversary of his receipt of the Nobel Prize.  He was the father of Carl Viggo Manthey Lange,  Halvard Lange and firstnameplaceholder August Manthey Lange.His daughter Thora was a history and language teacher, from 1938 at Oslo Cathedral School. During the occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany she joined the resistance movement while her husband went in exile. She was imprisoned at Grini concentration camp in September 1943, but fell ill and died at Ullevål Hospital in December.[2][3]Lange was a member of the Norwegian Association for Women's Rights.

Karl firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (Swedish pronunciation: [ˈjǎlmar ˈbrânːtɪŋ] (listen); 23 November 1860 – 24 February 1925) was a Swedish politician who was the leader of the Swedish Social Democratic Party (1907–1925) and Prime Minister during three separate periods (1920, 1921–1923 and 1924–1925). When secondnameplaceholder came to power in 1920, he was the first Social Democratic Prime Minister of Sweden. When taking office for a second term after the general election of 1921, he became the first socialist politician in Europe to do so following elections with universal suffrage. In 1921, secondnameplaceholder shared the Nobel Peace Prize with the Norwegian secretary-general of the Inter-Parliamentary Union Christian Lous Lange.
<h2>Biography</h2>
Born to the professor Lars Gabriel secondnameplaceholder and the noblewoman and pianist Emma af Georgii, secondnameplaceholder was educated in Stockholm and at Uppsala University. He developed a scientific background in mathematical astronomy and was an assistant at the Stockholm Observatory, but gave up his devotion to scientific work to become a journalist in 1884 and began editing the newspapers Tiden and Social-Demokraten. His decision to publish an article by the more radical socialist Axel Danielsson, a piece denounced by opponents as insulting to religious sensitivities, resulted in political convictions for blasphemy and imprisonment for both men.[1] secondnameplaceholder was imprisoned for three months in 1888.[2]Together with August Palm, secondnameplaceholder was one of the main organizers of the Swedish Social Democratic Party in 1889. He was its first Member of Parliament from 1896 and for six years the only one.In the early years of the 20th century, secondnameplaceholder led the Social Democrats in opposing a war to keep Norway united with Sweden. When the crisis came in 1905, he coined the slogan "Hands off Norway, King!" The Social Democrats organized resistance to a call-up of reserves and a general strike against a war and are credited with a substantial share in preventing one.secondnameplaceholder accepted Eduard Bernstein's revision of Marxism and became a reformist socialist, advocating a peaceful transition from capitalism towards socialism. He believed that if workers were given the vote, this could be achieved by parliamentary ways. secondnameplaceholder supported the February Revolution in Russia in 1917. He was pro-Menshevik and defended the government of Alexander Kerensky, whom he even personally visited in Petrograd.When the October Revolution broke out the same year, secondnameplaceholder condemned the Bolshevik seizure of power. 1917 saw a split in the Swedish Social Democratic Party on this question, and the youth league and the revolutionary sections of the party broke away and formed the Social Democratic Left Party of Sweden, headed by Zeth Höglund. This group soon became the Swedish Communist Party. Höglund later returned to the Social Democratic Party and wrote a two-volume biography about secondnameplaceholder.As Prime Minister, secondnameplaceholder brought Sweden into the League of Nations and was personally active as a delegate within it. When the question of whether Åland should be handed over to Sweden after the independence of Finland from Russia was brought up, he let the League of Nation decide upon the issue. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1921 for his work in the League of Nations, sharing the prize with the Norwegian Christian Lous Lange.
<h2>Monuments and memorials</h2>
secondnameplaceholder is commemorated by the secondnameplaceholder Monument in Stockholm. Additionally in Gothenburg, there is a tram and bus interchange named after secondnameplaceholder (Swedish: firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholdersplatsen). Stockholms Plads (Stockholm Square) in Copenhagen was renamed firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholders Plads in 1925.
