She had been detained before the elections and remained under house arrest for almost 15 of the 21 years from 1989 to 2010, becoming one of the world's most prominent political prisoners.[8] In 1999, Time magazine named her one of the "Children of Gandhi" and his spiritual heir to nonviolence.[9] She survived an assassination attempt in the 2003 Depayin massacre when at least 70 people associated with the NLD were killed.[10]Her party boycotted the 2010 elections, resulting in a decisive victory for the military-backed Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP). firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder became a Pyithu Hluttaw MP while her party won 43 of the 45 vacant seats in the 2012 by-elections. In the 2015 elections, her party won a landslide victory, taking 86% of the seats in the Assembly of the Union – well more than the 67% supermajority needed to ensure that its preferred candidates were elected president and second vice president in the presidential electoral college. Although she was prohibited from becoming the president due to a clause in the constitution – her late husband and children are foreign citizens – she assumed the newly created role of State Counsellor of Myanmar, a role akin to a prime minister or a head of government.When she ascended to the office of state counsellor, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder drew criticism from several countries, organisations and figures over Myanmar's inaction in response to the genocide of the Rohingya people in Rakhine State and refusal to acknowledge that Myanmar's military has committed massacres.[11][12][13][14][15] Under her leadership, Myanmar also drew criticism for prosecutions of journalists.[16] In 2019, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder appeared in the International Court of Justice where she defended the Burmese military against allegations of genocide against the Rohingya.[17]On 1 February 2021, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was arrested and deposed by the military during the 2021 Myanmar coup d'état after it declared the November 2020 Myanmar general election results, which the NLD won, fraudulent.[18] The coup sparked protests across the country.
<h2>Name</h2>
firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, like other Burmese names, includes no surname, but is only a personal name, in her case derived from three relatives: "firstnameplaceholder San" from her father, "Suu" from her paternal grandmother, and "Kyi" from her mother Khin Kyi.[19]The Burmese refer to her as Daw firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder. Daw, literally meaning "aunt", is not part of her name but is an honorific for any older and revered woman, akin to "Madam".[20] Burmese sometimes address her as Daw Suu or Amay Suu ("Mother Suu").[21][22][23][24][25][26][27][28]
<h2>Personal life</h2>
firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was born on 19 June 1945 in Rangoon (now Yangon), British Burma. According to Peter Popham, she was born in a small village outside Rangoon called Hmway Saung.[29] Her father, firstnameplaceholder San, allied with the Japanese during World War II. firstnameplaceholder San founded the modern Burmese army and negotiated Burma's independence from the United Kingdom in 1947; he was assassinated by his rivals in the same year. She grew up with her mother, Khin Kyi, and two brothers, firstnameplaceholder San Lin and firstnameplaceholder San Oo, in Rangoon. firstnameplaceholder San Lin died at the age of eight when he drowned in an ornamental lake on the grounds of the house.[19] Her elder brother emigrated to San Diego, California, becoming a United States citizen.[19] After firstnameplaceholder San Lin's death, the family moved to a house by Inya Lake where firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder met people of various backgrounds, political views, and religions.[30] She was educated in Methodist English High School (now Basic Education High School No. 1 Dagon) for much of her childhood in Burma, where she was noted as having a talent for learning languages.[31] She speaks four languages: Burmese, English, French, and Japanese.[32] She is a Theravada Buddhist.Suu Kyi's mother, Khin Kyi, gained prominence as a political figure in the newly formed Burmese government. She was appointed Burmese ambassador to India and Nepal in 1960, and firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder followed her there. She studied in the Convent of Jesus and Mary School in New Delhi, and graduated from Lady Shri Ram College, a constituent college of the University of Delhi in New Delhi, with a degree in politics in 1964.[33][34] Suu Kyi continued her education at St Hugh's College, Oxford, obtaining a B.A. degree in Philosophy, Politics and Economics in 1967,[35] graduating with a third-class degree[36][37][38] and M.A. degree in politics in 1968. After graduating, she lived in New York City with family friend Ma Than E, who was once a popular Burmese pop singer.[39] She worked at the United Nations for three years, primarily on budget matters, writing daily to her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris.[40] On 1 January 1972, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder and Aris, a scholar of Tibetan culture and literature, living abroad in Bhutan, were married.[33][41] The following year, she gave birth to their first son, Alexander Aris, in London; their second son, Kim, was born in 1977. Between 1985 and 1987, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was working toward a Master of Philosophy degree in Burmese literature as a research student at School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London.[42][43] She was elected as an Honorary Fellow of St Hugh's in 1990.[33] For two years, she was a Fellow at the Indian Institute of Advanced Studies (IIAS) in Shimla, India. She also worked for the government of the Union of Burma.In 1988, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder returned to Burma, at first to tend for her ailing mother but later to lead the pro-democracy movement. Aris' visit in Christmas 1995 turned out to be the last time that he and firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder met, as firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder remained in Burma and the Burmese dictatorship denied him any further entry visas.[33] Aris was diagnosed with prostate cancer in 1997 which was later found to be terminal. Despite appeals from prominent figures and organizations, including the United States, UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan and Pope John Paul II, the Burmese government would not grant Aris a visa, saying that they did not have the facilities to care for him, and instead urged firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder to leave the country to visit him. She was at that time temporarily free from house arrest but was unwilling to depart, fearing that she would be refused re-entry if she left, as she did not trust the military junta's assurance that she could return.[44]Aris died on his 53rd birthday on 27 March 1999. Since 1989, when his wife was first placed under house arrest, he had seen her only five times, the last of which was for Christmas in 1995. She was also separated from her children, who live in the United Kingdom, but starting in 2011, they have visited her in Burma.[45]On 2 May 2008, after Cyclone Nargis hit Burma, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's dilapidated lakeside bungalow lost its roof and electricity, while the cyclone also left entire villages in the Irrawaddy delta submerged.[46] Plans to renovate and repair the house were announced in August 2009.[47] Suu Kyi was released from house arrest on 13 November 2010.[48]
<h2>Political career</h2>
Coincidentally, when firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder returned to Burma in 1988, the long-time military leader of Burma and head of the ruling party, General Ne Win, stepped down. Mass demonstrations for democracy followed that event on 8 August 1988 (8–8–88, a day seen as auspicious), which were violently suppressed in what came to be known as the 8888 Uprising. On 26 August 1988, she addressed half a million people at a mass rally in front of the Shwedagon Pagoda in the capital, calling for a democratic government.[33] However, in September 1988, a new military junta took power.Influenced[49] by both Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of non-violence[50][51] and more specifically by Buddhist concepts,[52] firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder entered politics to work for democratization, helped found the National League for Democracy on 27 September 1988,[53] but was put under house arrest on 20 July 1989. She was offered freedom if she left the country, but she refused. Despite her philosophy of non-violence, a group of ex-military commanders and senior politicians who joined NLD during the crisis believed that she was too confrontational and left NLD. However, she retained enormous popularity and support among NLD youths with whom she spent most of her time.[54]During her time under house arrest, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder devoted herself to Buddhist meditation practices and to studying Buddhist thought. This deeper interest in Buddhism is reflected in her writings as more emphasis is put on love and compassion.[55] There also emerged more discussion on the compatibility of democracy and Buddhism and the ability to gain freedom from an authoritarian government through Buddhism.[56]During the crisis, the previous democratically elected Prime Minister of Burma, U Nu, initiated to form an interim government and invited opposition leaders to join him. Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi had signaled his readiness to recognize the interim government. However, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder categorically rejected U Nu's plan by saying "the future of the opposition would be decided by masses of the people". Ex-Brigadier General firstnameplaceholder Gyi, another influential politician at the time of the 8888 crisis and the first chairman in the history of the NLD, followed the suit and rejected the plan after firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's refusal.[57] firstnameplaceholder Gyi later accused several NLD members of being communists and resigned from the party.[54]In 1990, the military junta called a general election, in which the National League for Democracy (NLD) received 59% of the votes, guaranteeing NLD 80% of the parliament seats. Some[who?] claim that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder would have assumed the office of Prime Minister.[58] Instead, the results were nullified and the military refused to hand over power, resulting in an international outcry. firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was placed under house arrest at her home on University Avenue (16°49′32″N 96°9′1″E﻿ / ﻿16.82556°N 96.15028°E﻿ / 16.82556; 96.15028) in Rangoon, during which time she was awarded the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought in 1990, and the Nobel Peace Prize one year later. Her sons Alexander and Kim accepted the Nobel Peace Prize on her behalf. firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder used the Nobel Peace Prize's US$1.3 million prize money to establish a health and education trust for the Burmese people.[59] Around this time, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder chose non-violence as an expedient political tactic, stating in 2007, "I do not hold to non-violence for moral reasons, but for political and practical reasons."[60]The decision of the Nobel Committee mentions:[61]In 1995 firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder delivered the keynote address at the Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing.[62]On 9 November 1996, the motorcade that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was traveling in with other National League for Democracy leaders Tin Oo and Kyi Maung, was attacked in Yangon. About 200 men swooped down on the motorcade, wielding metal chains, metal batons, stones and other weapons. The car that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was in had its rear window smashed, and the car with Tin Oo and Kyi Maung had its rear window and two backdoor windows shattered. It is believed the offenders were members of the Union Solidarity and Development Association (USDA) who were allegedly paid 500 kyats (@ USD $0.50) each to participate. The NLD lodged an official complaint with the police, and according to reports the government launched an investigation, but no action was taken. (Amnesty International 120297)[63]firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was placed under house arrest for a total of 15 years over a 21-year period, on numerous occasions, since she began her political career,[64] during which time she was prevented from meeting her party supporters and international visitors. In an interview, she said that while under house arrest she spent her time reading philosophy, politics and biographies that her husband had sent her.[65] She also passed the time playing the piano and was occasionally allowed visits from foreign diplomats as well as from her personal physician.[66]Although under house arrest, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was granted permission to leave Burma under the condition that she never return, which she refused: "As a mother, the greater sacrifice was giving up my sons, but I was always aware of the fact that others had given up more than me. I never forget that my colleagues who are in prison suffer not only physically, but mentally for their families who have no security outside- in the larger prison of Burma under authoritarian rule."[67]The media were also prevented from visiting firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, as occurred in 1998 when journalist Maurizio Giuliano, after photographing her, was stopped by customs officials who then confiscated all his films, tapes and some notes.[68] In contrast, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder did have visits from government representatives, such as during her autumn 1994 house arrest when she met the leader of Burma, General Than Shwe and General Khin Nyunt on 20 September in the first meeting since she had been placed in detention.[33] On several occasions during her house arrest, she had periods of poor health and as a result was hospitalized.[69]The Burmese government detained and kept firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder imprisoned because it viewed her as someone "likely to undermine the community peace and stability" of the country, and used both Article 10(a) and 10(b) of the 1975 State Protection Act (granting the government the power to imprison people for up to five years without a trial),[70] and Section 22 of the "Law to Safeguard the State Against the Dangers of Those Desiring to Cause Subversive Acts" as legal tools against her.[71] She continuously appealed her detention,[72] and many nations and figures continued to call for her release and that of 2,100 other political prisoners in the country.[73][74] On 12 November 2010, days after the junta-backed Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP) won elections conducted after a gap of 20 years, the junta finally agreed to sign orders allowing firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's release,[75] and Suu Kyi's house arrest term came to an end on 13 November 2010.The United Nations (UN) has attempted to facilitate dialogue between the junta and firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder.[33] On 6 May 2002, following secret confidence-building negotiations led by the UN, the government released her; a government spokesman said that she was free to move "because we are confident that we can trust each other". firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder proclaimed "a new dawn for the country". However, on 30 May 2003 in an incident similar to the 1996 attack on her, a government-sponsored mob attacked her caravan in the northern village of Depayin, murdering and wounding many of her supporters.[76] firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder fled the scene with the help of her driver, Kyaw Soe Lin, but was arrested upon reaching Ye-U. The government imprisoned her at Insein Prison in Rangoon. After she underwent a hysterectomy in September 2003,[77] the government again placed her under house arrest in Rangoon.The results from the UN facilitation have been mixed; Razali Ismail, UN special envoy to Burma, met with firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder. Ismail resigned from his post the following year, partly because he was denied re-entry to Burma on several occasions.[78] Several years later in 2006, Ibrahim Gambari, UN Undersecretary-General (USG) of Department of Political Affairs, met with firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, the first visit by a foreign official since 2004.[79] He also met with Suu Kyi later the same year.[80] On 2 October 2007 Gambari returned to talk to her again after seeing Than Shwe and other members of the senior leadership in Naypyidaw.[81] State television broadcast firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder with Gambari, stating that they had met twice. This was firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's first appearance in state media in the four years since her current detention began.[82]The United Nations Working Group for Arbitrary Detention published an Opinion that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's deprivation of liberty was arbitrary and in contravention of Article 9 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights 1948, and requested that the authorities in Burma set her free, but the authorities ignored the request at that time.[83] The U.N. report said that according to the Burmese Government's reply, "Daw firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder has not been arrested, but has only been taken into protective custody, for her own safety", and while "it could have instituted legal action against her under the country's domestic legislation  ... it has preferred to adopt a magnanimous attitude, and is providing her with protection in her own interests".[83]Such claims were rejected by Brig-General Khin Yi, Chief of Myanmar Police Force (MPF). On 18 January 2007, the state-run paper New Light of Myanmar accused Suu Kyi of tax evasion for spending her Nobel Prize money outside the country. The accusation followed the defeat of a US-sponsored United Nations Security Council resolution condemning Burma as a threat to international security; the resolution was defeated because of strong opposition from China, which has strong ties with the military junta (China later voted against the resolution, along with Russia and South Africa).[84]In November 2007, it was reported that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder would meet her political allies National League for Democracy along with a government minister. The ruling junta made the official announcement on state TV and radio just hours after UN special envoy Ibrahim Gambari ended his second visit to Burma. The NLD confirmed that it had received the invitation to hold talks with Suu Kyi.[85] However, the process delivered few concrete results.On 3 July 2009, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon went to Burma to pressure the junta into releasing firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder and to institute democratic reform. However, on departing from Burma, Ban Ki-moon said he was "disappointed" with the visit after junta leader Than Shwe refused permission for him to visit firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, citing her ongoing trial. Ban said he was "deeply disappointed that they have missed a very important opportunity".[86]Protests led by Buddhist monks began on 19 August 2007 following steep fuel price increases, and continued each day, despite the threat of a crackdown by the military.[92]On 22 September 2007, although still under house arrest, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder made a brief public appearance at the gate of her residence in Yangon to accept the blessings of Buddhist monks who were marching in support of human rights.[93] It was reported that she had been moved the following day to Insein Prison (where she had been detained in 2003),[94][95][96][97] but meetings with UN envoy Ibrahim Gambari near her Rangoon home on 30 September and 2 October established that she remained under house arrest.[98][99]On 3 May 2009, an American man, identified as John Yettaw, swam across Inya Lake to her house uninvited and was arrested when he made his return trip three days later.[100] He had attempted to make a similar trip two years earlier, but for unknown reasons was turned away.[101] He later claimed at trial that he was motivated by a divine vision requiring him to notify her of an impending terrorist assassination attempt.[102] On 13 May, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was arrested for violating the terms of her house arrest because the swimmer, who pleaded exhaustion, was allowed to stay in her house for two days before he attempted the swim back. firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was later taken to Insein Prison, where she could have faced up to five years confinement for the intrusion.[103] The trial of firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder and her two maids began on 18 May and a small number of protesters gathered outside.[104][105] Diplomats and journalists were barred from attending the trial; however, on one occasion, several diplomats from Russia, Thailand and Singapore and journalists were allowed to meet firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder.[106] The prosecution had originally planned to call 22 witnesses.[107] It also accused John Yettaw of embarrassing the country.[108] During the ongoing defence case, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder said she was innocent. The defence was allowed to call only one witness (out of four), while the prosecution was permitted to call 14 witnesses. The court rejected two character witnesses, NLD members Tin Oo and Win Tin, and permitted the defence to call only a legal expert.[109] According to one unconfirmed report, the junta was planning to, once again, place her in detention, this time in a military base outside the city.[110] In a separate trial, Yettaw said he swam to Suu Kyi's house to warn her that her life was "in danger".[111] The national police chief later confirmed that Yettaw was the "main culprit" in the case filed against firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder.[112] According to aides, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder spent her 64th birthday in jail sharing biryani rice and chocolate cake with her guards.[113]Her arrest and subsequent trial received worldwide condemnation by the UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations Security Council,[114] Western governments,[115] South Africa,[116] Japan[117] and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, of which Burma is a member.[118] The Burmese government strongly condemned the statement, as it created an "unsound tradition"[119] and criticised Thailand for meddling in its internal affairs.[120] The Burmese Foreign Minister Nyan Win was quoted in the state-run newspaper New Light of Myanmar as saying that the incident "was trumped up to intensify international pressure on Burma by internal and external anti-government elements who do not wish to see the positive changes in those countries' policies toward Burma".[108] Ban responded to an international campaign[121] by flying to Burma to negotiate, but Than Shwe rejected all of his requests.[122]On 11 August 2009, the trial concluded with Suu Kyi being sentenced to imprisonment for three years with hard labour. This sentence was commuted by the military rulers to further house arrest of 18 months.[123] On 14 August, US Senator Jim Webb visited Burma, visiting with junta leader Gen. Than Shwe and later with Suu Kyi. During the visit, Webb negotiated Yettaw's release and deportation from Burma.[124] Following the verdict of the trial, lawyers of firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder said they would appeal against the 18-month sentence.[125] On 18 August, United States President Barack Obama asked the country's military leadership to set free all political prisoners, including firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder.[126] In her appeal, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder had argued that the conviction was unwarranted. However, her appeal against the August sentence was rejected by a Burmese court on 2 October 2009. Although the court accepted the argument that the 1974 constitution, under which she had been charged, was null and void, it also said the provisions of the 1975 security law, under which she has been kept under house arrest, remained in force. The verdict effectively meant that she would be unable to participate in the elections scheduled to take place in 2010 – the first in Burma in two decades. Her lawyer stated that her legal team would pursue a new appeal within 60 days.[127]firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder has received vocal support from Western nations in Europe,[128] Australia[128] and North[129] and South America, as well as India,[26] Israel,[130] Japan[131] the Philippines and South Korea.[132] In December 2007, the US House of Representatives voted unanimously 400–0 to award firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder the Congressional Gold Medal; the Senate concurred on 25 April 2008.[133] On 6 May 2008, President George W. Bush signed legislation awarding firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder the Congressional Gold Medal.[134] She is the first recipient in American history to receive the prize while imprisoned. More recently, there has been growing criticism of her detention by Burma's neighbours in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, particularly from Indonesia,[135] Thailand,[136] the Philippines[137][138] and Singapore.[139] At one point Malaysia warned Burma that it faced expulsion from ASEAN as a result of the detention of firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder.[140] Other nations including South Africa,[141] Bangladesh[142] and the Maldives[143] also called for her release. The United Nations has urged the country to move towards inclusive national reconciliation, the restoration of democracy, and full respect for human rights.[144] In December 2008, the United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution condemning the human rights situation in Burma and calling for firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's release—80 countries voting for the resolution, 25 against and 45 abstentions.[145] Other nations, such as China and Russia, are less critical of the regime and prefer to cooperate only on economic matters.[146] Indonesia has urged China to push Burma for reforms.[147] However, Samak Sundaravej, former Prime Minister of Thailand, criticised the amount of support for firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, saying that "Europe uses firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder as a tool. If it's not related to firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, you can have deeper discussions with Myanmar."[148]Vietnam, however, did not support calls by other ASEAN member states for Myanmar to free firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, state media reported Friday, 14 August 2009.[149] The state-run Việt Nam News said Vietnam had no criticism of Myanmar's decision 11 August 2009 to place firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder under house arrest for the next 18 months, effectively barring her from elections scheduled for 2010. "It is our view that the firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder trial is an internal affair of Myanmar", Vietnamese government spokesman Le Dung stated on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. In contrast with other ASEAN member states, Dung said Vietnam has always supported Myanmar and hopes it will continue to implement the "roadmap to democracy" outlined by its government.[150]Nobel Peace Prize winners (Archbishop Desmond Tutu, the Dalai Lama, Shirin Ebadi, Adolfo Pérez Esquivel, Mairead Corrigan, Rigoberta Menchú, Prof. Elie Wiesel, US President Barack Obama, Betty Williams, Jody Williams and former US President Jimmy Carter) called for the rulers of Burma to release firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder to "create the necessary conditions for a genuine dialogue with Daw firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder and all concerned parties and ethnic groups to achieve an inclusive national reconciliation with the direct support of the United Nations".[33] Some of the money she received as part of the award helps fund London-based charity Prospect Burma, which provides higher education grants to Burmese students.[151]It was announced prior to the 2010 Burmese general election that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder may be released "so she can organize her party",[152] However, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was not allowed to run.[153] On 1 October 2010 the government announced that she would be released on 13 November 2010.[154]US President Barack Obama personally advocated the release of all political prisoners, especially firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, during the US-ASEAN Summit of 2009.[155]The US Government hoped that successful general elections would be an optimistic indicator of the Burmese government's sincerity towards eventual democracy.[156] The Hatoyama government which spent 2.82 billion yen in 2008, has promised more Japanese foreign aid to encourage Burma to release firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder in time for the elections; and to continue moving towards democracy and the rule of law.[156][157]In a personal letter to firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, UK Prime Minister Gordon Brown cautioned the Burmese government of the potential consequences of rigging elections as "condemning Burma to more years of diplomatic isolation and economic stagnation".[158]Suu Kyi has met with many heads of state and opened a dialog with the Minister of Labor firstnameplaceholder Kyi (not to be confused with firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder).[159] She was allowed to meet with senior members of her NLD party at the State House,[160] however these meetings took place under close supervision.On the evening of 13 November 2010, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was released from house arrest.[161] This was the date her detention had been set to expire according to a court ruling in August 2009[162] and came six days after a widely criticised general election. She appeared in front of a crowd of her supporters, who rushed to her house in Rangoon when nearby barricades were removed by the security forces. firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder had been detained for 15 of the past 21 years.[163] The government newspaper New Light of Myanmar reported the release positively,[164] saying she had been granted a pardon after serving her sentence "in good conduct".[165] The New York Times suggested that the military government may have released Suu Kyi because it felt it was in a confident position to control her supporters after the election.[164] 
Her son Kim Aris was granted a visa in November 2010 to see his mother shortly after her release, for the first time in 10 years.[166] He visited again on 5 July 2011, to accompany her on a trip to Bagan, her first trip outside Yangon since 2003.[167] Her son visited again on 8 August 2011, to accompany her on a trip to Pegu, her second trip.[168]Discussions were held between Suu Kyi and the Burmese government during 2011, which led to a number of official gestures to meet her demands. In October, around a tenth of Burma's political prisoners were freed in an amnesty and trade unions were legalised.[169][170]In November 2011, following a meeting of its leaders, the NLD announced its intention to re-register as a political party to contend 48 by-elections necessitated by the promotion of parliamentarians to ministerial rank.[171] Following the decision, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder held a telephone conference with US President Barack Obama, in which it was agreed that Secretary of State Hillary Clinton would make a visit to Burma, a move received with caution by Burma's ally China.[172] On 1 December 2011, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder met with Hillary Clinton at the residence of the top-ranking US diplomat in Yangon.[173]On 21 December 2011, Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra met firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder in Yangoon, marking firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's "first-ever meeting with the leader of a foreign country".[174]On 5 January 2012, British Foreign Minister William Hague met firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder and his Burmese counterpart. This represented a significant visit for firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder and Burma. firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder studied in the UK and maintains many ties there, whilst Britain is Burma's largest bilateral donor.
During firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's visit to Europe, she visited the Swiss parliament, collected her 1991 Nobel Prize in Oslo and her honorary degree from the University of Oxford.[175]
[176][177]In December 2011, there was speculation that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder would run in the 2012 national by-elections to fill vacant seats.[178] On 18 January 2012, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder formally registered to contest a Pyithu Hluttaw (lower house) seat in the Kawhmu Township constituency in special parliamentary elections to be held on 1 April 2012.[179][180] The seat was previously held by Soe Tint, who vacated it after being appointed Construction Deputy Minister, in the 2010 election.[181] She ran against Union Solidarity and Development Party candidate Soe Min, a retired army physician and native of Twante Township.[182]On 3 March 2012, at a large campaign rally in Mandalay, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder unexpectedly left after 15 minutes, because of exhaustion and airsickness.[183]In an official campaign speech broadcast on Burmese state television's MRTV on 14 March 2012, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder publicly campaigned for reform of the 2008 Constitution, removal of restrictive laws, more adequate protections for people's democratic rights, and establishment of an independent judiciary.[184] The speech was leaked online a day before it was broadcast.[185] A paragraph in the speech, focusing on the Tatmadaw's repression by means of law, was censored by authorities.[186]Suu Kyi has also called for international media to monitor the upcoming by-elections, while publicly pointing out irregularities in official voter lists, which include deceased individuals and exclude other eligible voters in the contested constituencies.[187][188] On 21 March 2012, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was quoted as saying "Fraud and rule violations are continuing and we can even say they are increasing."[189]When asked whether she would assume a ministerial post if given the opportunity, she said the following:[190]On 26 March 2012, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder suspended her nationwide campaign tour early, after a campaign rally in Myeik (Mergui), a coastal town in the south, citing health problems due to exhaustion and hot weather.[191]On 1 April 2012, the NLD announced that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder had won the vote for a seat in Parliament.[192] A news broadcast on state-run MRTV, reading the announcements of the Union Election Commission, confirmed her victory, as well as her party's victory in 43 of the 45 contested seats, officially making firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder the Leader of the Opposition in the Pyidaungsu Hluttaw.[193]Although she and other MP-elects were expected to take office on 23 April when the Hluttaws resumed session, National League for Democracy MP-elects, including firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, said they might not take their oaths because of its wording; in its present form, parliamentarians must vow to "safeguard" the constitution.[194][195] In an address on Radio Free Asia, she said "We don't mean we will not attend the parliament, we mean we will attend only after taking the oath  ... Changing that wording in the oath is also in conformity with the Constitution. I don't expect there will be any difficulty in doing it."[196]On 2 May 2012, National League for Democracy MP-elects, including firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, took their oaths and took office, though the wording of the oath was not changed.[197] According to the Los Angeles Times, "Suu Kyi and her colleagues decided they could do more by joining as lawmakers than maintaining their boycott on principle."[197]
On 9 July 2012, she attended the Parliament for the first time as a lawmaker.[198]
[199]On 16 June 2012, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was finally able to deliver her Nobel acceptance speech (Nobel lecture) at Oslo's City Hall, two decades after being awarded the peace prize.[200][201] In September 2012, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder received in person the United States Congressional Gold Medal, which is the highest Congressional award. Although she was awarded this medal in 2008, at the time she was under house arrest, and was unable to receive the medal. firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was greeted with bipartisan support at Congress, as part of a coast-to-coast tour in the United States. In addition, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder met President Barack Obama at the White House. The experience was described by firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder as "one of the most moving days of my life."[202][203] In 2014, she was listed as the 61st most powerful woman in the world by Forbes.[204][205][206][207][208]On 6 July 2012, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder announced on the World Economic Forum's website that she wanted to run for the presidency in Myanmar's 2015 elections.[209] The current Constitution, which came into effect in 2008, bars her from the presidency because she is the widow and mother of foreigners – provisions that appeared to be written specifically to prevent her from being eligible.[210]The NLD won a sweeping victory in those elections, winning at least 255 seats in the House of Representatives and 135 seats in the House of Nationalities. In addition, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder won re-election to the House of Representatives. Under the 2008 constitution, the NLD needed to win at least a two-thirds majority in both houses to ensure that its candidate would become president. Before the elections, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder announced that even though she is constitutionally barred from the presidency, she would hold the real power in any NLD-led government.[211] On 30 March 2016 she became Minister for the President's Office, for Foreign Affairs, for Education and for Electric Power and Energy in President Htin Kyaw's government; later she relinquished the latter two ministries and President Htin Kyaw appointed her State Counsellor, a position akin to a Prime Minister created especially for her.[212][213][214][215][216][217] The position of State Counsellor was approved by the House of Nationalities on 1 April 2016 and the House of Representatives on 5 April 2016. The next day, her role as State Counsellor was established.As soon as she became foreign minister, she invited Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, Canadian Foreign Minister Stephane Dion and Italian Foreign Minister Paolo Gentiloni in April and Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida in May and discussed to have good diplomatic relationships with these countries.[218][219][220]Initially, upon accepting the State Counsellor position, she granted amnesty to the students who were arrested for opposing the National Education Bill, and announced the creation of the commission on Rakhine state, which had a long record of persecution of the Muslim Rohingya minority. However, soon firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's government did not manage with the ethnic conflicts in Shan and Kachin states, where thousands of refugees fled to China, and by 2017 the persecution of the Rohingya by the government forces escalated to the point that it is not uncommonly called a genocide. firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, when interviewed, has denied the allegations of ethnic cleansing.[221][222] She has also refused to grant citizenship to the Rohingya, instead taking steps to issue ID cards for residency but no guarantees of citizenship.[223]Her tenure as State Counsellor of Myanmar has drawn international criticism for her failure to address her country's economic and ethnic problems, particularly the plight of the Rohingya following the 25 August 2017 ARSA attacks (described as "certainly one of the biggest refugee crises and cases of ethnic cleansing since the Second World War"), for the weakening of freedom of the press and for her style of leadership, described as imperious and "distracted and out of touch".[224][225]During the COVID-19 pandemic in Myanmar, Suu Kyi chaired a National Central Committee responsible for coordinating the country's pandemic response.[226]In 2017, critics called for firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's Nobel prize to be revoked, citing her silence over the persecution of Rohingya people in Myanmar.[227][228]
Some activists criticised firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder for her silence on the 2012 Rakhine State riots (later repeated during the 2015 Rohingya refugee crisis), and her indifference to the plight of the Rohingya, Myanmar's persecuted Muslim minority.[229][230] In 2012, she told reporters she did not know if the Rohingya could be regarded as Burmese citizens.[231] In a 2013 interview with the BBC's Mishal Husain, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder did not condemn violence against the Rohingya and denied that Muslims in Myanmar have been subject to ethnic cleansing, insisting that the tensions were due to a "climate of fear" caused by "a worldwide perception that global Muslim power is 'very great'". She did condemn "hate of any kind" in the interview.[232] According to Peter Popham, in the aftermath of the interview, she expressed anger at being interviewed by a Muslim.[233] Husain had challenged Suu Kyi that almost all of the impact of violence was against the Rohingya, in response to firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's claim that violence was happening on both sides, and Peter Popham described her position on the issue as one of purposeful ambiguity for political gain.[234][page needed]However, she said that she wanted to work towards reconciliation and she cannot take sides as violence has been committed by both sides.[235] According to The Economist, her "halo has even slipped among foreign human-rights lobbyists, disappointed at her failure to make a clear stand on behalf of the Rohingya minority". However, she has spoken out "against a ban on Rohingya families near the Bangladeshi border having more than two children".[236]In a 2015 BBC News article, reporter Jonah Fisher suggested that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's silence over the Rohingya issue is due to a need to obtain support from the majority Bamar ethnicity as she is in "the middle of a general election campaign".[237] In May 2015, the Dalai Lama publicly called upon her to do more to help the Rohingya in Myanmar, claiming that he had previously urged her to address the plight of the Rohingya in private during two separate meetings and that she had resisted his urging.[238] In May 2016, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder asked the newly appointed United States Ambassador to Myanmar, Scot Marciel, not to refer to the Rohingya by that name as they "are not recognized as among the 135 official ethnic groups" in Myanmar.[239] This followed Bamar protests at Marciel's use of the word "Rohingya".[240]In 2016, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was accused of failing to protect Myanmar's Rohingya Muslims during the 2016–17 persecution.[241] State crime experts from Queen Mary University of London warned that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder is "legitimising genocide" in Myanmar.[242] Despite continued persecution of the Rohingya well into 2017, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was "not even admitting, let alone trying to stop, the army's well-documented campaign of rape, murder and destruction against Rohingya villages".[243] On 4 September 2017, Yanghee Lee, the UN's special rapporteur on human rights in Myanmar, criticised Suu Kyi's response to the "really grave" situation in Rakhine, saying: "The de facto leader needs to step in – that is what we would expect from any government, to protect everybody within their own jurisdiction."[244] The BBC reported that "Her comments came as the number of Rohingya fleeing to Bangladesh reached 87,000, according to UN estimates", adding that "her sentiments were echoed by Nobel Peace laureate Malala Yousafzai, who said she was waiting to hear from Ms Suu Kyi – who has not commented on the crisis since it erupted".[244] The next day George Monbiot, writing in The Guardian, called on readers to sign a change.org petition to have the Nobel peace prize revoked, criticising her silence on the matter and asserting "whether out of prejudice or out of fear, she denies to others the freedoms she rightly claimed for herself. Her regime excludes – and in some cases seeks to silence – the very activists who helped to ensure her own rights were recognised."[245] The Nobel Foundation replied that there existed no provision for revoking a Nobel Prize.[246] Archbishop Desmond Tutu, a fellow peace prize holder, also criticised Suu Kyi's silence: in an open letter published on social media, he said: "If the political price of your ascension to the highest office in Myanmar is your silence, the price is surely too steep  ... It is incongruous for a symbol of righteousness to lead such a country."[247] On 13 September it was revealed that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder would not be attending a UN General Assembly debate being held the following week to discuss the humanitarian crisis, with a Myanmar government spokesman stating "perhaps she has more pressing matters to deal with".[248]In October 2017, Oxford City Council announced that, following a unanimous cross-party vote,[249] the honour of Freedom of the City, granted in 1997 in recognition of her "long struggle for democracy", was to be withdrawn following evidence emerging from the United Nations which meant that she was "no longer worthy of the honour".[250] A few days later, Munsur Ali, a councillor for City of London Corporation, tabled a motion to rescind the Freedom of the City of London: the motion was supported by Catherine McGuinness, chair of the corporation's policy and resources committee, who expressed "distress  ... at the situation in Burma and the atrocities committed by the Burmese military".[249] On 13 November 2017, Bob Geldof returned his Freedom of the City of Dublin award in protest over firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder also holding the accolade, stating that he does not "wish to be associated in any way with an individual currently engaged in the mass ethnic cleansing of the Rohingya people of north-west Burma".  Calling firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder a "handmaiden to genocide",[251] Geldof added that he would take pride in his award being restored if it is first stripped from her.[252] The Dublin City Council voted 59–2 (with one abstention) to revoke firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's Freedom of the City award over Myanmar's treatment of the Rohingya people in December 2017, though Lord Mayor of Dublin Mícheál Mac Donncha denied the decision was influenced by protests by Geldof and members of U2.[253][254]  At the same meeting, the Councillors voted 37–7 (with 5 abstentions) to remove Geldof's name from the Roll of Honorary Freemen.[253][255]In March 2018, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum revoked Suu Kyi's Elie Wiesel Award, awarded in 2012, citing her failure "to condemn and stop the military's brutal campaign" against Rohingya Muslims.[256][257][258]In May 2018, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was considered complicit in the crimes against Rohingyas in a report by Britain's International Development Committee.[259]In August 2018, it was revealed that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder would be stripped of her Freedom of Edinburgh award over her refusal to speak out against the crimes committed against the Rohingya. She had received the award in 2005 for promoting peace and democracy in Burma.[260] This will be only the second time that anyone has ever been stripped of the award,[261][262] after Charles Stewart Parnell lost it in 1890 due to a salacious affair.[262] Also in August, a UN report, while describing the violence as genocide, added that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder did as little as possible to prevent it.[263]In early October 2018, both the Canadian Senate and its House of Commons voted unanimously to strip firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder of her honorary citizenship. This decision was caused by the Government of Canada's determination that the treatment of the Rohingya by Myanmar's government amounts to genocide.[264]On 11 November 2018, Amnesty International announced it was revoking her Ambassador of Conscience award.[265]
In December 2019, Suu Kyi appeared in the International Court of Justice at The Hague where she defended the Burmese military against allegations of genocide against the Rohingya.[17] In a speech of over 3,000 words, Suu Kyi did not use the term "Rohingya" in describing the ethnic group.[266]   She stated that the allegations of genocide were "incomplete and misleading",[17] claiming that the situation was actually a Burmese military response to attacks by the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army.[266] She also questioned how there could be "genocidal intent" when the Burmese government had opened investigations and also encouraged Rohingya to return after being displaced.[267][268] However, experts have largely criticized the Burmese investigations as insincere, with the military declaring itself innocent and the government preventing a visit from investigators from the United Nations.[268] Many Rohingya have also not returned due to perceiving danger and a lack of rights in Myanmar.[267]In January 2020, the International Court of Justice decided that there was a "real and imminent risk of irreparable prejudice to the rights" of the Rohingya. The court also took the view that the Burmese government's efforts to remedy the situation "do not appear sufficient" enough to protect the Rohingya. Therefore, the court ordered the Burmese government to take "all measures within its power" to protect the Rohingya from genocidal actions. The court also instructed the Burmese government to preserve evidence and report back to the court at timely intervals about the situation.[269][270]In December 2017, two Reuters journalists, Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, were arrested while investigating the Inn Din massacre of Rohingyas alleged to have been carried out by Myanmar's security forces.[271][272] Suu Kyi publicly commented in June 2018 that the journalists "weren't arrested for covering the Rakhine issue", but because they had broken Myanmar's Official Secrets Act.[272][273] As the journalists were then on trial for violating the Official Secrets Act, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's presumption of their guilt were criticized by rights groups for potentially influencing the verdict.[272][274] American diplomat Bill Richardson said that he had privately discussed the arrest with Suu Kyi, and he alleged that firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder reacted angrily and labelled the journalists "traitors".[275] A police officer testified that he was ordered by superiors to use entrapment to frame and arrest the journalists; he was later jailed and his family evicted from their home in the police camp.[276] The judge found the journalists guilty in September 2018 and to be jailed for seven years.[272] firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder reacted to widespread international criticism of the verdict by stating: "I don't think anyone has bothered to read" the judgement as it had "nothing to do with freedom of expression at all", but the Official Secrets Act. She also challenged critics to "point out where there has been a miscarriage of justice", and told the two Reuters journalists that they could appeal their case to a higher court.[277]In September 2018, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights issued a report that since firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's party, the NLD, came to power, the arrests and criminal prosecutions of journalists in Myanmar by the government and military, under laws which are too vague and broad, have "made it impossible for journalists to do their job without fear or favour."[16]On 1 February 2021, Suu Kyi was arrested and deposed by the Myanmar military, along with other leaders of her National League for Democracy (NLD) party, after the Myanmar military declared the November 2020 general election results fraudulent.[278][18] A 1 February court order authorized her detainment for 15 days, stating that soldiers searching her Naypyidaw villa had uncovered imported communications equipment lacking proper paperwork. Suu Kyi was transferred to house arrest on the same evening, and on 3 February was formally charged with illegally importing ten or more walkie-talkies. She faces up to three years in prison for the charges. According to the New York Times, the charge "echoed previous accusations of esoteric legal crimes (and) arcane offenses" used by the military against critics and rivals.[279] As of 9 February, Suu Kyi continues to be held incommunicado.[280]US President Joe Biden raised the threat of new sanctions as a result of the Myanmar military coup.[281] In a statement, the UN Secretary-General António Guterres believes "These developments represent a serious blow to democratic reforms in Myanmar." Volkan Bozkir, President of the UN General Assembly, also voiced his concerns, having tweeted "Attempts to undermine democracy and rule of law are unacceptable", and called for the "immediate release" of the detained NLD party leaders.[282]On 1 April 2021, Suu Kyi was charged with the fifth offence, a British-era colonial law of violating the official secrets act. According to her lawyer, it is the most serious charge brought against her after the coup and could carry a sentence of up to 14-years in prison if convicted.[283] On 12 April 2021, Suu Kyi was hit with another charge, this time "under section 25 of the natural disaster management law". According to her lawyer, it is her sixth indictment. She appeared in court via video link and now faces five charges in the capital Naypyidaw and one in Yangon.[284]On 28 April 2021, the National Unity Government (NUG), in which Suu Kyi symbolically remains in her position, anticipated that there would be no talks with the junta until all political prisoners, including her, are set free. This move by her supporters come after an ASEAN-supported consensus with the junta leadership in the past days.[285] However, on 8 May 2021, the junta designated NUG as a terrorist organization and warned citizens not to cooperate, or give aid to the parallel government, stripping Suu Kyi of her symbolic position.[286][287][288] On 10 May 2021, her lawyer said she would appear in court in person for the first time since her arrest after the Supreme Court ruled that she could attend in person and meet her lawyers. She had been previously only allowed to do so remotely from her home.[289] On 21 May 2021, a military junta commission was formed to dissolve Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD) on grounds of election fraud in the November 2020 election.[290] On 22 May 2021, during his first interview since the coup, junta leader Min firstnameplaceholder Hlaing reported that she was in good health at her home and that she would appear in court in a matter of days.[291] On 23 May 2021, the European Union expressed support for Suu Kyi's party and condemned the commission aimed at dissolving the party, echoing the NLD's statement released earlier in the week.[292]On 24 May 2021, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder appeared in person in court for the first time since the coup to face the "incitement to sedition" charge against her.[293] During the 30-minute hearing, she said that she was not fully aware of what was going on outside as she had no access to full information from the outside and refused to respond on the matters. She was also quoted on the possibility of her party forced dissolution as "Our party grew out of the people so it will exist as long as people support it."[294] In her meeting with her lawyers, Suu Kyi also wished people "good health."[294]On 2 June 2021, it was reported that the military had moved her (as well as Win Myint) from their homes to an unknown location.[295]On 10 June 2021, Suu Kyi was charged with corruption, the most serious charge brought against her, which carries a maximum penalty of 15 years' imprisonment. Suu Kyi's lawyers say the charges are made to keep her out of the public eye.[296]On 14 June 2021, the trial against Suu Kyi began. Any conviction would prevent her from running for office again.[297] Suu Kyi's lawyers attempted to have prosecution testimony against her on the sedition charge disqualified but the motion was denied by the judge.[298]
<h2>Political beliefs</h2>
Asked what democratic models Myanmar could look to, she said: "We have many, many lessons to learn from various places, not just the Asian countries like South Korea, Taiwan, Mongolia, and Indonesia." She also cited "the eastern Europe and countries, which made the transition from communist autocracy to democracy in the 1980s and 1990s, and the Latin American countries, which made the transition from military governments. And we cannot of course forget South Africa, because although it wasn't a military regime, it was certainly an authoritarian regime." She added: "We wish to learn from everybody who has achieved a transition to democracy, and also ... our great strong point is that, because we are so far behind everybody else, we can also learn which mistakes we should avoid."[300]In a nod to the deep US political divide between Republicans led by Mitt Romney and the Democrats of Obama—then battling to win the 2012 Presidential election—she stressed, "Those of you who are familiar with American politics I'm sure understand the need for negotiated compromise."[300]
<h2>In popular culture</h2>
The life of firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder and her husband Michael Aris is portrayed in Luc Besson's 2011 film The Lady, in which they are played by Michelle Yeoh and David Thewlis. Yeoh visited Suu Kyi in 2011 before the film's release in November.[325] In the John Boorman's 1995 film Beyond Rangoon, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was played by Adelle Lutz.[326]Since 2009,[327] Indian actress and Bharathanatyam dancer Rukmini Vijayakumar has been portraying firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder in a one-act play titled The Lady of Burma directed by Prakash Belawadi,[328][329] which also happens to be an eponymous play written by Richard Shannon.[330]Irish songwriters Damien Rice and Lisa Hannigan released in 2005 the single "Unplayed Piano", in support of the Free firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder 60th Birthday Campaign that was happening at the time.[331] U2's Bono wrote the song "Walk On" in tribute to firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, and publicized her plight during the U2 360° Tour, 2009–2011. Saxophonist Wayne Shorter composed a song titled "firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder". It appears on his albums 1+1 (with pianist Herbie Hancock) and Footprints Live!.[332]
<h2>Health problems</h2>
Suu Kyi underwent surgery for a gynecological condition in September 2003 at Asia Royal Hospital during her house arrest.[333] She also underwent minor foot surgery in December 2013 and eye surgery in April 2016.[334] Tin Myo Win, her doctor, said that she had no serious health problems but weighed only 48 kilograms (106 lb), had low blood pressure, and could become weak easily.[335]

firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Tum (Spanish: [riɣoˈβeɾta menˈtʃu]; born 9 January 1959)[1] is a K'iche' Guatemalan human rights activist, feminist,[2] and Nobel Peace Prize laureate. secondnameplaceholder has dedicated her life to publicizing the rights of Guatemala's Indigenous peoples during and after the Guatemalan Civil War (1960–1996), and to promoting Indigenous rights internationally.[3]She received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1992 and the Prince of Asturias Award in 1998, in addition to other prestigious awards. She is the subject of the testimonial biography I, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (1983) and the author of the autobiographical work, Crossing Borders (1998), among other works. secondnameplaceholder is a UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador. She ran for president of Guatemala in 2007 and 2011, having founded the country's first Indigenous political party, Winaq.[4]
<h2>Personal life</h2>
firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was born to a poor Indigenous family of Q'iche' Maya descent in Laj Chimel, a rural area in the north-central Guatemalan province of El Quiché.[5] Her family was one of many Indigenous families who could not sustain themselves on the small pieces of land they were left with after the Spanish conquest of Guatemala.[6] secondnameplaceholder's mother began her career as a midwife at age sixteen, and continued to practice using traditional medicinal plants until she was murdered at age 43. Her father was a prominent activist for the rights of Indigenous farmers in Guatemala.[7] Both of her parents regularly attended Catholic church, and her mother remained significantly connected to her Maya spirituality and identity.[7] secondnameplaceholder considers herself to be the perfect mix of both her parents.[7] She believes in many teachings of the Catholic Church, but her mother's Maya influence also taught secondnameplaceholder the importance of living in harmony with nature and retaining her Maya culture.[7]In 1979-80 her brother, Patrocinio, and her mother, Juana Tum Kótoja, were kidnapped, brutally tortured and murdered by the Guatemalan army.[3] Her father, Vicente secondnameplaceholder Perez, died in the 1980 Burning of the Spanish Embassy, which occurred after urban guerrillas took hostages and were attacked by government security forces.[8] In January 2015, Pedro García Arredondo, a former police commander of the Guatemalan army, was convicted of attempted murder and crimes against humanity for his role in the embassy attack.[8][9]In 1984, secondnameplaceholder's other brother, Victor, was shot to death after he surrendered to the Guatemalan army, was threatened by soldiers, and tried to escape.[10]In 1995, secondnameplaceholder married Ángel Canil, a Guatemalan, in a Mayan ceremony. They had a Catholic wedding in January 1998; at that time they also buried their son Tz'unun ("hummingbird" in Mayan), who had died after being born prematurely in December.[11] They adopted a son, Mash Nahual J’a ("Spirit of Water").[12][13]She lives with her family in the municipality of San Pedro Jocopilas, Quiché Department, northwest of Guatemalạ City, in the heartland of the Kʼicheʼ people.
<h2>Guatemalan activism</h2>
From a young age, secondnameplaceholder was active alongside her father, advocating for the rights of Indigenous farmers through the Committee for Peasant Unity.[14][7] secondnameplaceholder often faced discrimination for wanting to join her male family members in the fight for justice, but she was inspired by her mother to continue making space for herself.[15] She believes that the roots of Indigenous oppression in Guatemala stem from issues of exploitation and colonial land ownership.[14] Her early activism focused on defending her people from colonial exploitation.[14]After leaving school, secondnameplaceholder worked as an activist campaigning against human rights violations committed by the Guatemalan armed forces during the country's civil war, which lasted from 1960 to 1996.[10] Many of the human rights violations that occurred during the war targeted Indigenous peoples.[16] Women were targets of physical and sexual violence at the hands of the military.[17]In 1981, secondnameplaceholder was exiled and escaped to Mexico where she found refuge in the home of a Catholic bishop in Chiapas.[18]  secondnameplaceholder continued to organize resistance to oppression in Guatemala and organize the struggle for Indigenous rights by co-founding the United Republic of Guatemalan Opposition.[19] Tens of thousands of people, mostly Mayan Indians, fled to Mexico from 1982 to 1984 at the height of Guatemala's 36-year civil war.[19]A year later, in 1982, she narrated a book about her life, titled Me llamo firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder y así me nació la conciencia (My Name is firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, and this is how my Awareness was Born), to Venezuelan author and anthropologist Elizabeth Burgos, which was translated into five other languages including English and French.[5] secondnameplaceholder narrated the book in Spanish, although she had only learned to speak it three years prior.[14] Spanish was a language that had been forced upon Indigenous peoples by colonizers, but secondnameplaceholder sought to master the language and turn it against her oppressors.[14] The book made her an international icon at the time of the ongoing conflict in Guatemala and brought attention to the suffering of Indigenous peoples under an oppressive government regime.[5][20]secondnameplaceholder served as the Presidential Goodwill Ambassador for the 1996 Peace Accords in Guatemala.[21] That same year she received the Peace Abbey Courage of Conscience Award in Boston.[22]After the Guatemalan Civil War ended, secondnameplaceholder campaigned to have Guatemalan political and military establishment members tried in Spanish courts.[23] In 1999, she filed a complaint before a court in Spain because prosecutions of civil-war era crimes in Guatemala was practically impossible.[23] These attempts stalled as the Spanish courts determined that the plaintiffs had not yet exhausted all possibilities of seeking justice through the legal system of Guatemala.[23] On 23 December 2006, Spain called for the extradition from Guatemala of seven former members of Guatemala's government, including Efraín Ríos Montt and Óscar Mejía, on charges of genocide and torture.[24] Spain's highest court ruled that cases of genocide committed abroad could be judged in Spain, even if no Spanish citizens were involved.[24] In addition to the deaths of Spanish citizens, the most serious charges include genocide against the Maya people of Guatemala.[24]On 12 February 2007, secondnameplaceholder announced that she would form an Indigenous political party called Encuentro por Guatemala and that she would stand in the 2007 presidential election.[25] She was the first Maya, Indigenous woman to ever run in a Guatemalan election.[26] Had she been elected, she would have become Latin America's fourth Indigenous president after Mexico's Benito Juárez, Peru's Alejandro Toledo and Bolivia's Evo Morales.[27] In the 2007 election, secondnameplaceholder was defeated in the first round, receiving three percent of the vote.[28]In 2009, secondnameplaceholder became involved in the newly founded party Winaq.[25] secondnameplaceholder was a candidate for the 2011 presidential election, but lost in the first round, winning three percent of the vote again.[29] Although secondnameplaceholder was not elected, Winaq succeeded in becoming the first Indigenous political party of Guatemala.[4]
<h2>International activism</h2>
In 1996, secondnameplaceholder was appointed as a UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador in recognition of her activism for the rights of Indigenous people.[30] In this capacity, she acted as a spokesperson for the first International Decade of the World's Indigenous Peoples (1995–2004), where she worked to improve international collaboration on issues such as environment, education, health care, and human rights for Indigenous peoples.[31][32] In 2015, secondnameplaceholder met with the general director of UNESCO, Irina Bokova, in order to solidify relations between Guatemala and the organization.[33]Since 2003, secondnameplaceholder has become involved in the Indigenous pharmaceutical industry as president of "Salud para Todos" ("Health for All") and the company "Farmacias Similares," with the goal of offering low-cost generic medicines.[21][34] As president of this organization, secondnameplaceholder has received pushback from large pharmaceutical companies due to her desire to shorten the patent life of certain AIDS and cancer drugs to increase their availability and affordability.[34]In 2006, secondnameplaceholder was one of the founders of the Nobel Women's Initiative along with sister Nobel Peace Laureates Jody Williams, Shirin Ebadi, Wangari Maathai, Betty Williams and Mairead Corrigan Maguire.[35] These six women, representing North America, South America, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, decided to bring together their experiences in a united effort for peace, justice and equality.[35] It is the goal of the Nobel Women's Initiative to help strengthen women's rights around the world.[35]secondnameplaceholder is a member of PeaceJam, an organization whose mission is to use Nobel Peace Laureates as mentors and models for young people and provide a way for these Laureates to share their knowledge, passions, and experience.[36][37] She travels around the world speaking to youth through PeaceJam conferences.[36] She has also been a member of the Foundation Chirac's honor committee since the foundation was launched in 2008 by former French president Jacques Chirac in order to promote world peace.[38]secondnameplaceholder has continued her activism in recent years, according to the Prensa Latina, by continuing to raise awareness for issues including political and economic inequality and climate change.[39] She continues to be a spokesperson for human rights, including the current violations occurring in Venezuela.[40]
<h2>Legacy</h2>
More than a decade after the publication of I, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, anthropologist David Stoll investigated secondnameplaceholder's story and claimed that secondnameplaceholder changed some elements about her life, family, and village to meet the publicity needs of the guerrilla movement.[58] The controversy caused by Stoll's book received widespread coverage in the US press of the time.[59] The New York Times highlighted a few claims in her book contradicted by other sources:[60]Many authors have defended secondnameplaceholder, and attributed the controversy to different interpretations of the testimonio genre.[61][62][63][64] secondnameplaceholder herself states,  "I'd like to stress that it's not only my life, it's also the testimony of my people."[14] Despite accusations of factual and historical discrepancies, secondnameplaceholder's testimony remains relevant for the ways in which it depicts the life of an Indigenous Guatemalan during the civil war.[63]The Nobel Committee dismissed calls to revoke secondnameplaceholder's Nobel Prize, in spite of Stoll's allegations regarding secondnameplaceholder.[65] Geir Lundestad, the secretary of the committee, stated that secondnameplaceholder's prize was awarded because of her advocacy and social justice work, not because of her testimony, and that she had committed no observable wrongdoing.[5][41]According to Mark Horowitz, William Yaworsky, and Kenneth Kickham, the controversy about Stoll's account of Menchu is one of the three most divisive episodes in recent American anthropological history, along with controversies about the truthfulness of Margaret Mead's Coming of Age in Samoa and Napoleon Chagnon's representation of violence among the Yanomami.[66]

firstnameplaceholder Rolihlahla secondnameplaceholder (/mænˈdɛlə/;[1] Xhosa: [xolíɬaɬa mandɛ̂ːla]; 18 July 1918 – 5 December 2013) was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary, political leader and philanthropist who served as President of South Africa from 1994 to 1999. He was the country's first Black head of state and the first elected in a fully representative democratic election. His government focused on dismantling the legacy of apartheid by tackling institutionalised racism and fostering racial reconciliation. Ideologically an African nationalist and socialist, he served as the president of the African National Congress (ANC) party from 1991 to 1997.A Xhosa speaker, secondnameplaceholder was born to the Thembu royal family in Mvezo, Union of South Africa. He studied law at the University of Fort Hare and the University of Witwatersrand before working as a lawyer in Johannesburg. There he became involved in anti-colonial and African nationalist politics, joining the ANC in 1943 and co-founding its Youth League in 1944. After the National Party's white-only government established apartheid, a system of racial segregation that privileged whites, he and the ANC committed themselves to its overthrow. secondnameplaceholder was appointed president of the ANC's Transvaal branch, rising to prominence for his involvement in the 1952 Defiance Campaign and the 1955 Congress of the People. He was repeatedly arrested for seditious activities and was unsuccessfully prosecuted in the 1956 Treason Trial. Influenced by Marxism, he secretly joined the banned South African Communist Party (SACP). Although initially committed to non-violent protest, in association with the SACP he co-founded the militant Umkhonto we Sizwe in 1961 and led a sabotage campaign against the government. He was arrested and imprisoned in 1962, and subsequently sentenced to life imprisonment for conspiring to overthrow the state following the Rivonia Trial.secondnameplaceholder served 27 years in prison, split between Robben Island, Pollsmoor Prison and Victor Verster Prison. Amid growing domestic and international pressure and fears of racial civil war, President F. W. de Klerk released him in 1990. secondnameplaceholder and de Klerk led efforts to negotiate an end to apartheid, which resulted in the 1994 multiracial general election in which secondnameplaceholder led the ANC to victory and became president. Leading a broad coalition government which promulgated a new constitution, secondnameplaceholder emphasised reconciliation between the country's racial groups and created the Truth and Reconciliation Commission to investigate past human rights abuses. Economically, secondnameplaceholder's administration retained its predecessor's liberal framework despite his own socialist beliefs, also introducing measures to encourage land reform, combat poverty and expand healthcare services. Internationally, he acted as mediator in the Pan Am Flight 103 bombing trial and served as secretary-general of the Non-Aligned Movement from 1998 to 1999. He declined a second presidential term and was succeeded by his deputy, Thabo Mbeki. secondnameplaceholder became an elder statesman and focused on combating poverty and HIV/AIDS through the charitable firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Foundation.secondnameplaceholder was a controversial figure for much of his life. Although critics on the right denounced him as a communist terrorist and those on the far left deemed him too eager to negotiate and reconcile with apartheid's supporters, he gained international acclaim for his activism. Widely regarded as an icon of democracy and social justice, he received more than 250 honours, including the Nobel Peace Prize. He is held in deep respect within South Africa, where he is often referred to by his Thembu clan name, Madiba, and described as the "Father of the Nation".
<h2>Early life</h2>
secondnameplaceholder was born on 18 July 1918 in the village of Mvezo in Umtata, then part of South Africa's Cape Province.[2] Given the forename Rolihlahla,[3] a Xhosa term colloquially meaning "troublemaker",[4] in later years he became known by his clan name, Madiba.[5] His patrilineal great-grandfather, Ngubengcuka, was king of the Thembu people in the Transkeian Territories of South Africa's modern Eastern Cape province.[6] One of Ngubengcuka's sons, named secondnameplaceholder, was firstnameplaceholder's grandfather and the source of his surname.[7] Because secondnameplaceholder was the king's child by a wife of the Ixhiba clan, a so-called "Left-Hand House", the descendants of his cadet branch of the royal family were morganatic, ineligible to inherit the throne but recognised as hereditary royal councillors.[8]firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's father, Gadla Henry Mphakanyiswa secondnameplaceholder (1880–1928), was a local chief and councillor to the monarch; he was appointed to the position in 1915, after his predecessor was accused of corruption by a governing white magistrate.[9] In 1926, Gadla was also sacked for corruption, but firstnameplaceholder was told that his father had lost his job for standing up to the magistrate's unreasonable demands.[10] A devotee of the god Qamata,[11] Gadla was a polygamist with four wives, four sons and nine daughters, who lived in different villages. firstnameplaceholder's mother was Gadla's third wife, Nosekeni Fanny, daughter of Nkedama of the Right Hand House and a member of the amaMpemvu clan of the Xhosa.[12]secondnameplaceholder later stated that his early life was dominated by traditional Thembu custom and taboo.[14] He grew up with two sisters in his mother's kraal in the village of Qunu, where he tended herds as a cattle-boy and spent much time outside with other boys.[15] Both his parents were illiterate, but being a devout Christian, his mother sent him to a local Methodist school when he was about seven. Baptised a Methodist, secondnameplaceholder was given the English forename of "firstnameplaceholder" by his teacher.[16] When secondnameplaceholder was about nine, his father came to stay at Qunu, where he died of an undiagnosed ailment which secondnameplaceholder believed to be lung disease.[17] Feeling "cut adrift", he later said that he inherited his father's "proud rebelliousness" and "stubborn sense of fairness".[18]secondnameplaceholder's mother took him to the "Great Place" palace at Mqhekezweni, where he was entrusted to the guardianship of the Thembu regent, Chief Jongintaba Dalindyebo. Although he did not see his mother again for many years, secondnameplaceholder felt that Jongintaba and his wife Noengland treated him as their own child, raising him alongside their son, Justice, and daughter, Nomafu.[19] As secondnameplaceholder attended church services every Sunday with his guardians, Christianity became a significant part of his life.[20] He attended a Methodist mission school located next to the palace, where he studied English, Xhosa, history and geography.[21] He developed a love of African history, listening to the tales told by elderly visitors to the palace, and was influenced by the anti-imperialist rhetoric of a visiting chief, Joyi.[22] Nevertheless, at the time he considered the European colonizers not as oppressors but as benefactors who had brought education and other benefits to southern Africa.[23] Aged 16, he, Justice and several other boys travelled to Tyhalarha to undergo the ulwaluko circumcision ritual that symbolically marked their transition from boys to men;
